Dear Family and Friends,

Did you know there are 27 million people forced into slavery around the globe, most of whom are children...children without a voice? Human Sex Trafficking is the fastest-growing business of organized crime and the third-largest criminal enterprise in the world. The majority of sex trafficking is international, with victims taken from such places as South and Southeast Asia, the former Soviet Union, Central and South America, and other less developed areas and moved to more developed ones, including Asia, the Middle East, Western Europe, and North America.

I am running a campaign in support of an organization called The Exodus Road that utilizes undercover investigators around the world to fuel the rescues of victims of sex trafficking, all with local police partners in SE Asia and India. The majority of these rescues are underage victims. With more slaves today than at any other time in human history, they are strategically equipping an army of trained, skilled investigators to assist police conduct raids, rescues and arrests. You can find out more about the organization by visiting the website here:www.theExodusRoad.com. They are a 501c3 in good standing with both the state and federal government, and all gifts are tax-deductible.

While The Exodus Road works mostly to bring interventions into the fight against sex slavery, this campaign is an after care project. I am looking raise $1000 in 45 days to send 4 exploited children to school. $250 sends one of these children to school by covering their uniform, book, and entrance fees for an entire year. Will you help me bring restoration to a former victim of abuse or slavery? Together, we can let them know that their pasts do not have to be their futures.
Your donation will make a life-changing difference in a child’s life.
Even if you can't donate financially, help me by spreading the word! SHARE my campaign on your Facebook wall.
You can also connect with The Exodus Road on Facebook (@The Exodus Road)  to get current updates by liking our page or following us on Twitter (@theexodusroad).

If you'd like text updates to your phone of real-time raids and operations, text ""ER"" to #51555. 

Thank you in advance for your help with this urgent matter!

Most appreciatively,

Patti Tree

Hello friends and family, I would like to let you know about
what I’ve been doing and how you can help.
Last year I had the opportunity to visit a friend teaching a
school for Karen refuges on the Thai/Burma boarder and ended up teaching for a
month. Burma has been undergoing one of the longest civil wars in history.
Including some of the most atrocious human rights violations the world has
seen. This war is being fought between the Burmese majority and the ethnic
minorities of Burma, Karen being the largest of the minority groups.
Since meeting Karen people my life has been changed so much.
Each day I am amazed by the beauty and the gentleness of their souls, something
that is quite rare from anyone - let alone people who have endured so much. My
heart was hungry to  know these people, I
knew I had to come back, teach, live with and be taught by the Karen.
I left America on
October 7<sup>th</sup> and after multiple flights, trains, and buses I arrived
at Thoo Mwe Khee School just outside of Phop Phra, Thailand on October 9<sup>th</sup>.
Thoo Mwe Khee is a migrant school for Karen minorities of
Burma and is about a mile from the border of Burma. There are about 300
students that live on-site and about 600 altogether. My reason for being in
this fantastic place is to teach. I am a teacher of about 100 students. My
background is the health care field so I teach Health Science, something that I
am very excited to be teaching. The government of Burma spends less than 3% on
health care and almost nothing on educating. Some of the students had never
seen a diagram of the human body or know nothing about hygiene and sanitation.
Despite this, many of my students want to be nurses and doctors. Having been
raised in a war zone this is understandable, as many of them having seen
atrocities we cannot even fathom.  Being
able to educate them about common diseases, first aid, and basic health care is
an invaluable blessing and a great necessity.
In addition to health I also teach social studies -
something that I’m also very passionate about. Many of them are from villages
without any connection to the world outside. Being at Thoo Mwe Khee is the
first time many of them have seen computers, guitars, and white people. So

teaching them Social studies is and honor and a treat. 

My days are spent teaching, lesson planning and
fellowshipping with my students. I have little time for much else, but I will
keep you all posted more in the future.
What you can do to help?
Thoo Mwe Khee is very poor, so I don’t get paid for
teaching. Only two meals are provided a day usually consisting of rice and fish
paste (fermented fish guts) so I sometimes buy snacks or meals out and eggs. I
also have to pay for all of my teaching material, including countless copies
from the local print shop, medical supplies for teaching, as well as medical
supplies for the students (I’ve become a little bit of a school nurse) and other
random expenses, like driving students to the clinic which is 45 minutes away.
I would be most grateful if you would give to me
financially, I’m looking to raise about $1,500, which will cover all my living,
teaching, and medical supplies expenses as well as a plane ticket home. If you
would like to pray for me and send me encouragement that is also much needed.
But I encourage each of you to research the Karen people more, as many cities
have a Karen community. So If you have the opportunity, go and meet them. I
promise you will be changed too.

column1: Your support is crucial to the outcome of the symposium. By helping us reach our goal, we will be able to develop a strong foundation and core curriculum for offering collective insight training.  With additional funding, we can build a website that will host a collaborative college.

Because it is important to have a larger community be a part of this special event, we have designed the symposium so you can participate in many different ways. With a $ 40 donation you can join our social media site where you will receive real-time blog posts of what is happening ""on the ground"" so to speak, and participate with people like yourself who are enthusiastic and curious about collective insight. These will include photographs and short videos. You will meet and interact with others who, like you, are interested in building these emergent capacities.

At the $60 level you will receive private links to raw video footage of the symposium, which will include direct addresses and candid interviews. Up this to $80 and you will receive an Alderlore Insight Center T-shirt that will support our further work.

On Friday night and on Saturday night from 7-8:30 pm(Eastern), we will be live broadcasting two special events. Designed as a panel-on-panel ""rapid fire"" exchange, on all things arising -- these spontaneous discussions are sure to be extraordinarily fertile sessions. To participate, and add your voice to the fire, select Friday Night Lights or Saturday Night Fever (or both).

Those of you who will not be around to participate in real time, can opt to receive a dropbox of all the blog, video and livestream material in a post-production package by supporting us at the $ 200 level. Add an Alderlore T-Shirt, and you won't miss a beat.

For those who are interested in doing more, and be a part of the ongoing practice that emerges, there are three options. At the $ 400 level you can get started with a short training session which includes training material. At the $1200 level we offer customized coaching for facilitating collective insight. If you represent a team or group who could benefit from collective insight training, we offer a one-day on-site workshop given by Alderlore Insight Center faculty -- this for $ 3000 (travel and expenses not included). Your support at the $ 6000 level reserves the retreat studio at Alderlore Insight Center for you and up to 5 other people for a 4-day intensive that will immerse you in collective insight practice.

column2: >When similar events are held at convention centers, a greater percentage of the community's money is spent on outside products and services. Because the symposium is being held at Alderlore Insight Center, all the donations will go to benefit and further this work and sustain more initiatives like this.

column4: >Please spread the news about the symposium, about our work, and most importantly about this campaign for support. Tap into as many friends and family members as you can to donate even at the $ 25 level, because
column7: >this work is important to you.
column10: >As our communities of inquiry and practice grow larger and more distributed, it is crucial to keep investing in leading-edge research around topics and practices that are helping to create the future we hold in our hearts.

column1: (The following is a transcript of this video presentation):

Collective Insight is the experience of a group of people working together all having the same key insight at the same time. Although one or two individuals might speak it first, each person experiences the insight, the “ah ha” moment, spontaneously and at the same time, so there is very little impression that one or another individual came up with the idea. On the contrary, people report the feeling of already knowing what the person was going to say, or alternately, the feeling of having someone “take the words right out of my mouth.”

Collective Insight can be compared to a group of musicians from different bands and different styles coming together to play. At first they are each playing in their own sound, so it just sounds like an arbitrary mixture of competing riffs. As they search for a sound that is completely new, the result goes through phases of dissonance and experiment. Without any previous idea of what the result will be, and without needing anything like agreement or consensus on this form or that, the group can spontaneously settle into a completely new sound – something that surprises even them. Together, they begin to “hear” the form that is shaping, that is moving them toward an emergent new way of playing that has never been played before.

We already know quite a few things about collective insight. We know it is a special and rare outcome of group interaction.  We know that collective Insight is emergent, embodied, creative, spontaneous, imaginative, playful and powerful. Although most people have difficulty describing it, every person knows it when they experience it. In fact, outside observers who come in after the fact can tell when a group has achieved collective insights. We know that collective insight is powerful because it taps into creativity that is greater than the sum total of the individuals in the group. We know that it depends upon people in the group having a sufficient orientation toward letting go of their individual patterns of behavior, thinking, doing, and saying, while also being willing to abandon what they know in lieu of what they might be surprised to learn, and able to allow themselves to flow with emotional, dialogic, conceptual and relational movements through all kinds of phases and in any and all directions.

We know that collective insight requires the ability to stick with the engagement during the oftentimes long process of working through the uncomfortable periods when nothing seems to be happening, or everything seems to be going wrong. We know that these are periods which are very similar to natural adaptive processes, in which many configurations of outcomes are tried, but few achieve the right “fit” or resonance. In these periods, a bright idea might fizzle out while deep silence or dark tension might spark a wave of inspiration. We know that the process depends strongly on relational dynamics, and that relational dynamics are non-linear and ride strong waves of emotional energy and subtle energetics. Finally, we know that it is impossible to determine what is a “beneficial” contribution and what is not, since everything that happens contributes to the adaptive process, which can benefit from contributions that can feel pleasant or unpleasant, and that therefore, the greatest potential for collective insights happens in groups where people learn to be equanimous with the process and happy to participate without expectation of outcome.

For a little more than 20 years small groups of people around the world have been experimenting with different versions of collective engagement. The earliest attempts at group alignment, such as world café, focus on forms of outward communication and forms of presentation. With the introduction of Otto Scharma’s U-theory the focus turned toward quality of the internal state or presence of the individuals participating in group activities. Ria Baeck has carried this into the practice of collective presencing. Bill Torbert introduced the system of action-logics and its role in leadership, while Terri O’Fallon’s GTC program focuses on the role of higher stages and states of awareness in facilitating transformative change. More recently  Terry Patten coined the term “trans-rhetorical” and others have used the term “generative discourse” to signify a new type of discourse that leads to or arises within groups that practice  what Dustin DiPerna has called transpersonal “inter-being.”  Still, other practices rely on transpersonal states of spiritual arousal that open and deepen awareness toward a kind of trans-individual being, as reported by a core group of practitioners of Enlighten Next.

Almost all the practices we mentioned have taken place within groups that self-select based on community needs, shared values, or spiritual commitments. We can consider these practices as community-specific. Community-specific practices are in some sense “primed” by specialized language, shared memes, formal and sometimes rigorous rules of engagement – whether explicitly stated or operating implicitly. While these conditions maintain group cohesion, they can also intensify peer pressure and create false consciousness.

Despite this, and because of this, all the people participating in this symposium have been very careful to delineate specific approaches that steer clear of the conventional traps of collective practice. This symposium brings these traditions together for the first time to engage as peers – all on the same level, all in the same “soup” as it were – to practice collective insight. The practice we will perform will not be pre-stated, but must arise from the co-creative and emergent “fermentation process”, to use a tour from Bruno Latour – the form of the practice must arise from a kind of fermentation of what we bring, individually and collectively, to the engagement. We will be open to being surprised, and welcome what comes next.

This is both a challenging and exciting prospect. What will we find out about ourselves? What will we witness about the process of engaging as peers? What principles of collective practice will we discover? What significant insights will come, in the spontaneous co-creative relational dynamics that will course through our 4 days together.

If we can derive principles  for generating collective insight in groups where there are few selection criteria, and where people represent a broad range of values and oftentimes “competing” worldviews – then we have a powerful practice for addressing 21 Century problems. How often our communities, our businesses, our organizations, our governments, stymied by dysfunctional means of discourse and pathological ways of being together. Relational dynamics are more often destructive than generative in groups, especially where the topics are complex and the stakes are very high.

If we can set out a rigorous set of principles for collective insight, that is not values or world-view specific, but is methodological in scope and processural in practice, then we have the possibility of bringing collective insight-training into a much larger context.

column3: >Alderlore Inc. is a 501C3 not-for-profit retreat center located in Winsted, CT. It is our home location for Alderlore Insight Center.   We provide professional services to individuals and groups and educational programs to youth and adults. Since its inception, Alderlore has donated more than 2000 hours to on-line, co-creative transformative education.

column1: ","16 Pioneers  2 Decades of Research & Praxis

Designed as a panel-on-panel ""rapid fire"" exchange, on all things arising -- these spontaneous discussions are sure to be extraordinarily fertile sessions. To participate, and add your voice to the fire, select Friday Night Lights or Saturday Night Fever (or both).

Those of you who will not be around to participate in real time, can opt to receive a dropbox of all the blog, video and livestream material in a post-production package by supporting us at the $ 200 level. Add an Alderlore T-Shirt, and you won't miss a beat.

For those who are interested in doing more, and be a part of the ongoing practice that emerges, there are three options. At the $ 400 level you can get started with a short training session which includes training material. At the $1200 level we offer customized coaching for facilitating collective insight. If you represent a team or group who could benefit from collective insight training, we offer a one-day on-site workshop given by Alderlore Insight Center faculty -- this for $ 3000 (travel and expenses not included). Your support at the $ 6000 level reserves the retreat studio at Alderlore Insight Center for you and up to 5 other people for a 4-day intensive that will immerse you in collective insight practice.

When similar events are held at convention centers, a greater percentage of the community's money is spent on outside products and services. Because the symposium is being held at Alderlore Insight Center, all the donations will go to benefit and further this work and sustain more initiatives like this.

Please spread the news about the symposium, about our work, and most importantly about this campaign for support. Tap into as many friends and family members as you can to donate even at the $ 25 level, because this work is important to you. As our communities of inquiry and practice grow larger and more distributed, it is crucial to keep investing in leading-edge research around topics and practices that are helping to create the future we hold in our hearts.
(The following is a transcript of this video presentation):

Collective Insight is the experience of a group of people working together all having the same key insight at the same time. Although one or two individuals might speak it first, each person experiences the insight, the “ah ha” moment, spontaneously and at the same time, so there is very little impression that one or another individual came up with the idea. On the contrary, people report the feeling of already knowing what the person was going to say, or alternately, the feeling of having someone “take the words right out of my mouth.”

Collective Insight can be compared to a group of musicians from different bands and different styles coming together to play. At first they are each playing in their own sound, so it just sounds like an arbitrary mixture of competing riffs. As they search for a sound that is completely new, the result goes through phases of dissonance and experiment. Without any previous idea of what the result will be, and without needing anything like agreement or consensus on this form or that, the group can spontaneously settle into a completely new sound – something that surprises even them. Together, they begin to “hear” the form that is shaping, that is moving them toward an emergent new way of playing that has never been played before.

We already know quite a few things about collective insight. We know it is a special and rare outcome of group interaction.  We know that collective Insight is emergent, embodied, creative, spontaneous, imaginative, playful and powerful. Although most people have difficulty describing it, every person knows it when they experience it. In fact, outside observers who come in after the fact can tell when a group has achieved collective insights. We know that collective insight is powerful because it taps into creativity that is greater than the sum total of the individuals in the group. We know that it depends upon people in the group having a sufficient orientation toward letting go of their individual patterns of behavior, thinking, doing, and saying, while also being willing to abandon what they know in lieu of what they might be surprised to learn, and able to allow themselves to flow with emotional, dialogic, conceptual and relational movements through all kinds of phases and in any and all directions.We know that collective insight requires the ability to stick with the engagement during the oftentimes long process of working through the uncomfortable periods when nothing seems to be happening, or everything seems to be going wrong. We know that these are periods which are very similar to natural adaptive processes, in which many configurations of outcomes are tried, but few achieve the right “fit” or resonance. In these periods, a bright idea might fizzle out while deep silence or dark tension might spark a wave of inspiration. We know that the process depends strongly on relational dynamics, and that relational dynamics are non-linear and ride strong waves of emotional energy and subtle energetics. Finally, we know that it is impossible to determine what is a “beneficial” contribution and what is not, since everything that happens contributes to the adaptive process, which can benefit from contributions that can feel pleasant or unpleasant, and that therefore, the greatest potential for collective insights happens in groups where people learn to be equanimous with the process and happy to participate without expectation of outcome.

For a little more than 20 years small groups of people around the world have been experimenting with different versions of collective engagement. The earliest attempts at group alignment, such as world café, focus on forms of outward communication and forms of presentation. With the introduction of Otto Scharma’s U-theory the focus turned toward quality of the internal state or presence of the individuals participating in group activities. Ria Baeck has carried this into the practice of collective presencing. Bill Torbert introduced the system of action-logics and its role in leadership, while Terri O’Fallon’s GTC program focuses on the role of higher stages and states of awareness in facilitating transformative change. More recently  Terry Patten coined the term “trans-rhetorical” and others have used the term “generative discourse” to signify a new type of discourse that leads to or arises within groups that practice  what Dustin DiPerna has called transpersonal “inter-being.”  Still, other practices rely on transpersonal states of spiritual arousal that open and deepen awareness toward a kind of trans-individual being, as reported by a core group of practitioners of Enlighten Next.

Almost all the practices we mentioned have taken place within groups that self-select based on community needs, shared values, or spiritual commitments. We can consider these practices as community-specific. Community-specific practices are in some sense “primed” by specialized language, shared memes, formal and sometimes rigorous rules of engagement – whether explicitly stated or operating implicitly. While these conditions maintain group cohesion, they can also intensify peer pressure and create false consciousness.

Despite this, and because of this, all the people participating in this symposium have been very careful to delineate specific approaches that steer clear of the conventional traps of collective practice. This symposium brings these traditions together for the first time to engage as peers – all on the same level, all in the same “soup” as it were – to practice collective insight. The practice we will perform will not be pre-stated, but must arise from the co-creative and emergent “fermentation process”, to use a tour from Bruno Latour – the form of the practice must arise from a kind of fermentation of what we bring, individually and collectively, to the engagement. We will be open to being surprised, and welcome what comes next.This is both a challenging and exciting prospect. What will we find out about ourselves? What will we witness about the process of engaging as peers? What principles of collective practice will we discover? What significant insights will come, in the spontaneous co-creative relational dynamics that will course through our 4 days together.

If we can derive principles  for generating collective insight in groups where there are few selection criteria, and where people represent a broad range of values and oftentimes “competing” worldviews – then we have a powerful practice for addressing 21 Century problems. How often our communities, our businesses, our organizations, our governments, stymied by dysfunctional means of discourse and pathological ways of being together. Relational dynamics are more often destructive than generative in groups, especially where the topics are complex and the stakes are very high.

If we can set out a rigorous set of principles for collective insight, that is not values or world-view specific, but is methodological in scope and processural in practice, then we have the possibility of bringing collective insight-training into a much larger context.

Alderlore Inc. is a 501C3 not-for-profit retreat center located in Winsted, CT. It is our home location for Alderlore Insight Center.   We provide professional services to individuals and groups and educational programs to youth and adults. Since its inception, Alderlore has donated more than 2000 hours to on-line, co-creative transformative education.",19.0,2,"1 Campaign

column1: ","Become a supporter of The Third International Symposium on Korean Adoption Studies and join us at the AK Connection Mini Symposium!On Saturday, February 2, 2013 AK Connection will host a Mini Symposium to help kick off the Third International Symposium on Korean Adoption Studies (TISKAS) at the 2013 IKAA Gathering.  This Mini Symposium will include research presentations by local adoption scholars plus a special appearance by Deann Borshay Liem about her upcoming project, Geographies of Kinship. The event will take place at Macalester College, in St. Paul, MN

Your gift will support programming for the Symposium in July 2013.  These funds will help bring Korean Adoption Studies scholars from four continents representing eight different academic disciplines to Korea for the Symposium, and will also defray the administrative costs of holding the event.We need to raise $7,000 to make all of this possible.  By helping us reach this goal, you will be contributing to the success of the Mini Symposium and TISKAS at the 2013 IKAA Gathering.  Supporting Korean Adoption Studies at the Mini Symposium and TISKAS helps open doors for international adoption research in the future.  Please note that with every donation/sponsor level you receive a perk!
ADDITIONAL INFORMATION:
To learn more about the AK Connection Mini Symposium and program, please visit: www.akconnection.com
To learn more about the 2013 IKAA Gathering Conference, please visit: www.ikaa.org

<h2><span style=""line-height: 1.45em
Playground <span style=""font-weight: normal
column2: >""Nurturing Nature Education, One Preschooler at a Time.""

column1: you remember building forts as a child?  What about making mud pies,
picking dandelions, climbing trees or just playing outside until dusk?
Most adults today count childhood nature experiences among their fondest
memories.
Sadly, while direct
childhood experience with nature is critical, it is rapidly diminishing.
Parents and teachers cite hectic schedules, safety concerns, an increase in
indoor play facilities and the strong lure of technology as impediments to
nature experiences.  While some community parks offer children
playgrounds, the play that occurs on equipment is often sterile, limited in
scope and variety by the design of the equipment, rather than the imagination
of the child. Meanwhile, natural resources have diminished and childhood
obesity has become a recognized epidemic.  In Arizona, our extreme climate
and the harsh desert further complicate this issue.
Fortunately, by participating
in small grass-root efforts in our communities, we have an opportunity to make
changes now that will make impact the lives of future generations.  By
developing an innovative, nature-based outdoor playground, Pinnacle Presbyterian
Preschool will foster qualities such as curiosity, confidence, health and
learning during a critical window of development in early childhood.  With
your help, we can provide our preschoolers rich and varied nature experiences.
Accredited by the National
Association for the Education of Young Children (NAEYC) and inspired by the
active, project-based learning in the schools of Reggio Emilia Italy, Pinnacle
embraces the environment as a reflection of our values toward children.
In fact, along with parents and educators, we call the environment the “third
teacher”.  We believe children have a right to learn in beautiful spaces
designed just for them.  Both indoor and outdoor areas are intentionally
and thoughtfully structured to nurture the physical, social-emotional and
intellectual development of the preschooler.  Our proposed ""Nature Explorer Playground"", seeks to
“unplug” children from technology and support healthy development of the Whole
Child.  The Nature Explorer Playground evolves
from the real needs of children, offers activities that are engaging and
meaningful to them and fully embraces developmentally appropriate practice
within the Arizona Early Childhood Learning Standards.
Current research supports that nature play is not a luxury but a
necessity and a crucial element of healthy physical, intellectual and
social-emotional development for children of all ages. Here are some facts
about the benefits of unstructured, outdoor play:
-Outdoor learning can be an
important extension of indoor learning.Outdoor
space “should be used not only for the enhancement of physical skills but also
for the development of children’s social, emotional, creative, and cognitive
abilities”  (Isenberg &amp
-Children who have frequent
access to the <b><span>outdoors ""gain competence in moving
through the larger world."" (National Association for the
Education of Young Children)
-""Free and unstructured play
is essential for helping children reach <b><span>important social, emotional,
and cognitive developmental milestones."" ( American Academy of
Pediatrics)
-Schools with environmental
education programs score higher on standardized tests in math, reading,
writing and listening. ( Bartosh, Oksana. Environmental Education: Improving
Student Achievement. Thesis. Evergreen State College, 2003)
-Childhood nature experiences can
be an important pathway to adult environmental attitudes and
behaviors. (Wells, N. M., &amp
column2: Lekies, K. S. (2006). “Nature and the life

column1: course: Pathways from childhood nature experiences to adult environmentalism.”)
-Children’s stress levels fall within minutes of seeing green
spaces. ( Kuo, PhD, Frances E., and Andrea Faber Taylor, PhD. ""A Potential
Natural Treatment for Attention- Deficit/Hyperactivity Disorder: Evidence From
a National Study."" American Journal of Public Health 94.9. Sept. 2004)
-Outdoor play increases fitness levels and builds active,
healthy bodies, an important strategy in helping the one in three American kids
who are obese get fit. (CDC's National Center for Chronic Disease Prevention
and Health Promotion. Division of Adolescent and School Health. Childhood
Obesity. 20 Oct. 2008)
Funds raised from this project
will go directly towards the enhancement of our current play space to provide
outdoor experiences that encourage children to explore nature and enjoy
unstructured play.  The proposed learning areas on our playground will
include:
Gardening Area-Children will
have access to a “cutting garden”, where they will be encouraged to harvest
loose materials to use in their play.  They will also cultivate garden
beds to grow vegetable or flower gardens, play with worms and practice
nurturing plants.  This area will house our Mud Kitchen for rich sensory
and imaginary play and a Rock Garden that they can create and change over time.
Dramatic Play-Near the music
area, we will create an outdoor stage with open-ended costume materials, props
and fabric.  Here, children will be invited to sing, dance and act out
different roles and personas safely and confidently.
Math and Science Station-This area will
house tools that children can use to explore their outdoor environment though
math and science.  Items might include binoculars, tape measures, an
outdoor scale, magnifiers and clipboards or whiteboard panels.  It will
house a weather station where children will be invited to explore instruments
such as a thermometer, barometer, windsock, weather vane, rain gauge and
sundial.
Engineering Zone-This space
will surround the existing sandbox.  It will house a loose-parts
construction area where children can learn about building their own creations
out of a variety of parts and connectors such as logs, rocks, tree stumps and
wood planks.  Nearby, we will create a water feature with a pump so that
the children can use water in their sand play and a bucket and pulley system
for transporting items.
Inviting, Shady Spaces-
A must in the Arizona desert!  Cozy shaded, willow “fort” areas for the
children to explore, circular  benches under our shade tree and a covered
gazebo area for children to gather around for special programs, discussions,
and lessons.
Music Area-
Near the back wall of our outdoor space, we will create a music area with a
variety of simple conventional and unconventional instruments for children to
use to explore their own musical talents and interests.  We will include
at least three permanent, large-scale instruments- chimes, steel drums and an
akimbra.
for Nature Playground
A breakdown of the $10,000
budget for the Nature Playground
Gardening Area- $1,000
•Building of Mud Kitchen Area &
•Building of raised planters for Cutting Garden
&amp
•Building of Worm Digging Area &
•Building of Rock Garden Structure/Labor

•Costumes &
Math and Science Station-

Engineering Zone-$2,000

•Set of Large Hollow Outdoor Building Blocks
•Building of water feature with trough/Materials &
Inviting, Shady Spaces- $2,000

•Building of Story Benches under Shade Tree &
Materials/Labor

Materials/Labor
•Smaller mobile Musical Instruments
We thank your for your time and
consideration of our project.  We are a 501c3 non-profit
corporation and all donations are tax deductible.  Receipts will be
provided for donations.

Hello -

The ability to read, understand, write, and to do basic calculations is taken for granted by many of us. If we didn’t have those skills, imagine how life would be. Imagine how difficult it would be in 2013 to do many of the daily activities we consider commonplace. Activities such as reading signs, following directions, budgeting, and planning.
In 2011 there were an estimated 39 million Americans who didn’t have a high school diploma. Some have very high literacy and computational skills

At the Julia West House, a registered nonprofit organization, we offer free tutoring in literacy and GED® Test preparation to students at every level of competency and ability. Some need just a few weeks to achieve high test scores while others dedicate many months to study and preparation before taking the tests. Some never complete the tests, but gain enough new skills that they can function much more intelligently and effectively.

All of our tutors are volunteers. Some tutor one adult learner, once a week. Others tutor multiple students once or multiple times each week. Tutoring sessions are all one-on-one, lasting an hour, an hour and a half, or two hours each.
Who

Our adult learners look to Julia West House for opportunities, support, and encouragement. The Julia West House has been an outreach for Portland, Oregon residents for over 20 years. Our mission, to serve low-income and homeless residents, has not changed. Our outreach and services have changed as we have adjusted to meet the changing needs of the community and those we serve. In 2005 we began GED® Test preparation and literacy tutoring. We are now focused on programs that help people break cycles of harmful habits and behavior, find purpose, and find work.
Why

The GED® Test program is changing in profound ways. Instead of paper and books, the program will be entirely on-line. The focus is on a test-taker’s lifecycle—from a better study experience to a smooth transition into a job or postsecondary education. Today, adult learners compete in a new economic and global market. More jobs call for skilled, educated labor, requiring additional training and education beyond a high school diploma.
What

GED® traing and testing is moving from printed course material (books, worksheets, and tests) to a 100% computer-based and highly interactive instructional model. The program focuses on core competencies and preparing test takers for the next step in their education.

In order for our adult learners to continue their development, we need to obtain the computers, software, support, and supplies that allow us to use the new GED training and testing program for study and training. The items we need and the cost are:
<ul>
• $2,500 - 5 laptop computers for student study stations
• $600 - 1 laptop computer for the GED/Literacy coordinator
• $300 - 1 laser printer
• $8,250 - 5 GED® software licenses (3 years @$2,750/year)
• $500 - Technical support for set up
• $250 - Supplies
• $1,000 - 5 carrels for study stations
Total =  $13,250
If we don’t receive full funding at this time, we will buy GED® software licenses for a single year for $2,750, or for two years for $5,500.
This will provide us the equipment and resources to schedule 100 tutoring sessions each week.
When

Beginning in January, 2014, GED® Testing Services is changing to create a new test delivery and assessment system that will fundamentally improve adult education. We need to acquire and install hardware, software, and study stations by November, 2013, to be able to train our volunteers, and to be ready to cutover to the new GED Test system on January 2, 2014.
Impact

You will help people change their lives and move forward with purpose.You will help adults find better jobs, or find their first jobs. You will help families become stronger because a parent gains employment, or gets a better job. You will help families become stronger when a parent becomes a role model because she or he achieves GED® certification.
It will happen if you

Link, blog, like, and share the campaign. Your enthusiasm is contagious and will make this campaign a success. Even if you don’t think your friends and followers will donate, it is very helpful to have assistance in spreading the word.
For more information about the Julia West House, visit www.juliawest.org or email info@juliawest.org.

For more information about GED® Testing Services, visit www.gedtestingservices.com.

Some need just a few weeks to achieve high test scores while others dedicate many months to study and preparation before taking the tests. Some never complete the tests, but gain enough new skills that they can function much more intelligently and effectively.

All of our tutors are volunteers. Some tutor one adult learner, once a week. Others tutor multiple students once or multiple times each week. Tutoring sessions are all one-on-one, lasting an hour, an hour and a half, or two hours each.
Who

Our adult learners look to Julia West House for opportunities, support, and encouragement. The Julia West House has been an outreach for Portland, Oregon residents for over 20 years. Our mission, to serve low-income and homeless residents, has not changed. Our outreach and services have changed as we have adjusted to meet the changing needs of the community and those we serve. In 2005 we began GED® Test preparation and literacy tutoring. We are now focused on programs that help people break cycles of harmful habits and behavior, find purpose, and find work.
Why

The GED® Test program is changing in profound ways. Instead of paper and books, the program will be entirely on-line. The focus is on a test-taker’s lifecycle—from a better study experience to a smooth transition into a job or postsecondary education. Today, adult learners compete in a new economic and global market. More jobs call for skilled, educated labor, requiring additional training and education beyond a high school diploma.
What

GED® traing and testing is moving from printed course material (books, worksheets, and tests) to a 100% computer-based and highly interactive instructional model. The program focuses on core competencies and preparing test takers for the next step in their education.

In order for our adult learners to continue their development, we need to obtain the computers, software, support, and supplies that allow us to use the new GED training and testing program for study and training. The items we need and the cost are:
$2,500 - 5 laptop computers for student study stations
$600 - 1 laptop computer for the GED/Literacy coordinator
$300 - 1 laser printer
$8,250 - 5 GED® software licenses (3 years @$2,750/year)
$500 - Technical support for set up
$250 - Supplies
$1,000 - 5 carrels for study stations
If we don’t receive full funding at this time, we will buy GED® software licenses for a single year for $2,750, or for two years for $5,500.
This will provide us the equipment and resources to schedule 100 tutoring sessions each week.
When

Beginning in January, 2014, GED® Testing Services is changing to create a new test delivery and assessment system that will fundamentally improve adult education. We need to acquire and install hardware, software, and study stations by November, 2013, to be able to train our volunteers, and to be ready to cutover to the new GED Test system on January 2, 2014.
Impact

You will help people change their lives and move forward with purpose.You will help adults find better jobs, or find their first jobs. You will help families become stronger because a parent gains employment, or gets a better job. You will help families become stronger when a parent becomes a role model because she or he achieves GED® certification.
It will happen if you

Link, blog, like, and share the campaign. Your enthusiasm is contagious and will make this campaign a success. Even if you don’t think your friends and followers will donate, it is very helpful to have assistance in spreading the word.
For more information about the Julia West House, visit www.juliawest.org or email info@juliawest.org.
For more information about GED® Testing Services, visit www.gedtestingservices.com.",0.0,0,"1 Campaign
|","Portland, United States",https://www.indiegogo.com/projects/feed-a-hungry-mind/pica

We are journalists and free speech activists. We have
campaigned on behalf of journalists around the world because we believe everyone
should be free to share information and ideas. We don't want politicians
telling journalists what to write: we just need news we can trust.
We are setting up an independent self-regulator for the press
as recommended by Lord Justice Leveson after his year-long inquiry. We want
journalists to be able to defend themselves against libel bullies. And we want
ordinary people to be able to challenge and correct journalists when they get
things wrong or their stories cause real harm. The big newspaper groups are
refusing to meet the public's wish for independent self-regulation, so it's up
to us to solve this problem, once and for all.
We have worked with amazing journalists who have exposed
abuse and corruption around the world. Some of them have paid for their courage
with their lives. Others work under the constant fear of imprisonment and
torture. We are lucky in the UK that our press is free to hold the powerful to
account. Independent self-regulation can only strengthen this freedom, by rebuilding
the public's trust in journalism and giving journalists the confidence to tell
the stories that matter, without fear or favour.
The IMPRESS Project has already received a grant for £5,000
from the Joseph Rowntree Reform Trust. We need to match this with £5,375 in
public donations to pay for a series of meetings and events in spring 2014. We
have budgeted for staffing costs of £7,000
printing &amp

column3: and a contingency of £500. These meetings will allow us to finalise our

column1: plans for a new regulator, to be launched later this year. We will fundraise separately for the significant costs of launching the regulator itself.
We need to tour the United Kingdom, talking to journalists and
ordinary people about the kind of press they want to see in this country. Do you want to read news, in
print and online, that you can trust? Do you believe that newspaper owners
should be left to regulate themselves? Or do you agree that independent self-regulation is the right solution? If so, please support this project, get in
touch via the website: www.impressproject.org, and come to our events. We want
press regulation that works for the press, for the public.

The goal is to build a primary school house. If funds collected exceed the goal, the surplus will be used to build a sport complex for the children. It will include a skate park and cycling track, a football pitch and a basket ball and volleyball court.

A dream school for village children in Cambodia - Phase 2

column1: Thanks to the generosity of our friends far and near, our first
campaign on indiegogo was a success (www.indiegogo.com/CambodiaSchool)
We have delivered on our promise and the nursery school is
now standing tall and beautiful.
Its unique architecture is a happy blend of tradition and
modernity.  The beautiful three layer thatched roof provides a relief from
the heat. The bamboo walls filter the light and provide natural ventilation.
There are no acs, no fans in our school. We go green as much as possible. A
bio-digester provides cooking gas and solar panels donated by Panasonic Germany will
power the water pump and light the place.
The beautiful indoors and outdoors classroom are named after our
generous donors. They are now open to the first batch of children from the
neighborhood, 25 in all. 23 of them are from destitute families. Some are past
nursery age but have never been to school. So we take them and teach them Khmer
too.
With three teachers – myself and two assistants – the teacher /
students ratio is just right. When our school moves from Phnom Penh, with all the staff, the place
will be able to accommodate up to 80 students. This will happen in September 2015,
when the lease of the present school in Phnom
Penh expires.
We now need a building to house the primary classes. It is the
purpose of the present campaign. We appeal to you who believe in us to help us
make this dream come true again. This is phase 2 of Seametrey Children’s
Village, a school that provides poor Khmer children with quality education
which would otherwise be out of their reach.
The building will be again a house in the same style and spirit
as the nursery one. It is just larger with 3 classrooms that can comfortably
accommodate 25 children each, an administration room, a staff room and a
meeting room. The total cost will be US$30,000 including $5000 for equipment.
For the price of a standard car, we will build a house of knowledge for 75
children and not any house but one which is unique in its concept and design,
simple, humble and yet beautiful and inspiring.
You have seen us deliver on our past promise. We will deliver
again on this one. Seametrey is a name you can trust. On behalf of our children,

thank you for your help.

You can know all about me here:

 http://www.csmonitor.com/World/Making-a-difference/2011/0711/Muoy-You-who-escaped-Cambodia-s-killing-fields-now-teaches-self-respect-and-integrity

Major freeze killed off about 45% of Syrah vines.  My goal is to restore the dead part of the vineyard by purchasing 2 year old cuttings of Syrah grape vines. This will be the cost for the grape vine rooted cuttings  and labor.  

Syrah Grape vines are somewhat rare in the Antelope valley with the limited vineyards, which are located there.  

  • Hello, My name is Phil Barone, and I thought that I would give this campaign a try to see if this works.  I am in the negotiation phase of purchasing this vineyard, and would like to raise some capital for the revitalization of the vineyard, which it sorely needs.
<span style=""line-height: 1.45em
column2:
>This would be a goodwill gesture on my part to help the owner with funding to replant the lost vines, which was a heartbreak to see, as a major cold snap hit most of Southern California in April of last year.  If this request for funds is met, then I would be able to show the owner that I will make a goodwill gesture in the form of replenishing the losses from the freeze. I will then be able to determine that I am able, with the success of this campaign, to move forward with the second phase of this endeavor, to raise capital for a down payment, for the owner who is willing to hold the note--instead of a banking institution--which would probably make it almost impossible for this venture.    

 

  • This campaign is important to me, as it will allow us to take over the vineyard as owners/steward, and to partner with SET-FREE MINISTRIES, a non-profit organization, located in Phelan, CA, who have expressed total participation to supply labor, for a monthly fee.  I in turn would educate the labor force in the art of wine growing --individuals who have the desire to turn their life around. This will complete the dream that the current owner had until health issues robbed him of his ability to work.


  • This campaign, if successful, would allow me to become a winemaker/grower on a larger scale, devoting my time to the vineyard. I would eventually like to turn the property into a wine tasting business...rivaling some of the properties in Santa Barbara County.  My plan is to work with the wine growers association and to participate in the development of a wine trail through the Antelope Valley. Wine tasting has so much potential to grow in this area, and this would help the economy and give laborers a specialized skill.  This will ultimately be a major positive growth for the Antelope Valley. 

 

  • Five thousand dollars would be ideal to replace the vines killed off by the rare frost damage. Vines that are two years old would be purchased for approximately $5.00 per vine. There needs to be at least a total of 350 vines. 

 

  • The additional funds would go into the labor required to plant the vines. The irrigation is already set up, and the stakes, which secure the vines, are already in place.

 

  • The funds will go entirely to this project, even if the goal is not met.  Contributions/funds will be placed in a bank account set aside for this project.
column3: >This will be the beginning of a wonderful opportunity for individuals to live on site at the vineyard and to help with the upkeep, labor, and security of the grapevines.
column4:
> 

  • I have a passion to revive this vineyard, transforming it to what the original owner intended with his dream... and I will make that happen. I do currently own a small vineyard, so I already know what it takes. Many partners are at the helm, ready to go to work. I will supply before-and after photographs of the vineyard, using the YouTube feature of this presentation, so that everyone can see for himself or herself what is at stake. Anything that you can fund is well worth your investment, and it will be greatly appreciated! 

 

If anyone can also help by spreading the word, it would really be great. Feel free to share this on your Facebook Wall.

 

Thanks for everything you folks can do in order to meet this initial small goal. 

 

Phil

column5: >Help Us Move and Rebuild the Original TechShop Menlo Park!

column1: My name is Jim Newton, and I am the founder of TechShop. I started TechShop because I needed a place to build my hundreds of projects. It turned out that a lot of other people needed the same thing, and that's what has made TechShop such a success!

I started TechShop because I am a maker, and I personally needed access to a wide range of tools and equipment so I could build my hundreds of ideas. Originally I planned to only build one TechShop (this one in Menlo Park), but it turned out that the idea was a lot bigger than I had anticipated, so we quickly began to expand.
The land where our original location in Menlo Park is located is being redeveloped, so we have to move TechShop Menlo Park to a new location by Halloween 2013!

As part of the TechShop Menlo Park community, we ask you to consider backing this Indiegogo campaign in any way you can in order to help us raise $2.5 million so we can move TechShop Menlo Park, and rebuild it as the best TechShop location yet!
<hr/>
<span style=""font-size: 18pt
TechShop is America's first and largest membership-based do-it-yourself workshop that empowers its members to build all the things they have always wanted to make.
Here is a brief video about TechShop and features a few of our members who use TechShop to make an impact on the world, and their own lives:
<hr/>
<span style=""font-size: 18pt

I opened the first TechShop in Menlo Park back in October 2006, before there were any hackerspaces or makerspaces in the US. We couldn't just look at another makerspace and copy their model, so we had to design it from scratch. But with the help of our amazing community, we were able to fund it and get it open. Members of our community helped by telling everyone they knew about the TechShop idea, by pre-purchasing memberships, by providing us with $25,000 loans, and by volunteering to help us actually build the facility. As a result, we opened the doors of the very first TechShop on October 1, 2006...almost exactly 7 years ago.
As demand grew, we went on to build TechShop San Francisco and TechShop San Jose and crowd-funded more than $5 million for those two locations before there was even such a thing as ""crowd-funding"".

Today we have six TechShop locations across the US (TechShop Menlo Park, TechShop San Francisco, TechShop San Jose, TechShop Detroit, TechShop Austin, and TechShop Pittsburgh) and five more locations in development including TechShop Chandler AZ in partnership with Arizona State University, which will open in November 2013.
Our mission is to open hundreds of TechShop locations in the US and other countries and provide everyone with the tools of innovation so they can make amazing things and change the world.

We employ over 120 full-time employees, hundreds of part-time instructors, and we currently serve nearly 6,000 active members including 850 active members at TechShop Menlo Park. Thousands of people take classes at TechShop every month.

TechShop has enabled many of its members to launch businesses and products, including some world-changing products and a lot of very successful campaigns on Indiegogo and other crowd-funding platforms.

TechShop Menlo Park was our very first location...where it all started. I have a personal love for this beat-up old location, and lots of our members love it despite its blemishes. But now TechShop Menlo Park is in danger of being closed if we can't raise funding to move it to a new location.
<hr/>
<span style=""font-size: 18pt
column5: >We Have To Move or Close Down!

column1: As part of a planned development that has been in the works for a while, our Menlo Park building along with all the other buildings on our block are now slated to be demolished.  So we need to move out of our current building before October 31, 2013...Halloween!
<hr/>
<span style=""font-size: 18pt

We actually see this turn of events as a very positive opportunity for us to make TechShop Menlo Park even better than it is now and add all the new programs that the other TechShop members enjoy.  Yes, the situation is urgent, and if we can't raise the funding we need, then we will need to suspend operations of TechShop Menlo Park, but we are hopeful that you and the rest of the community will step forward and help us raise the money we need and move and rebuild TechShop Menlo Park!
<hr/>
<span style=""font-size: 18pt
We've learned a lot and made a lot of improvements in the TechShop model since we opened this first location back in 2006.

The new TechShop Menlo Park will feature all brand-new tools and equipment. Right now, TechShop Menlo Park still has a lot of the old used equipment that we started with, but it will all be replaced. If we meet our funding goals, we are going to try our best to add some exciting new program areas including a Flow water jet cutter just like we have in all our other locations, an expanded automotive area with a car lift, a licensed and certified commercial kitchen for member use along with a variety of new cooking classes, a jewelry studio complete with a vacuum metal casting foundry, an expanded electronics lab with all new equipment including LabView software and hardware, a large flex room that can be split into smaller rooms for large and small events and includes a back-of-house catering kitchen for food service at events, and lots more.

When we build a new TechShop location as we have in San Francisco, San Jose, Detroit, Austin, and Pittsburgh, it takes us about 5 months to design it, get permits, complete the construction, order all the new equipment, and install everything. We have a lot of experience with this now and we have gotten pretty good at it. We anticipate that the permanent new location facility for TechShop Menlo Park will also take about 5 months to build. The problem is that we have to be out of the current building long before then. So rather than shut down TechShop Menlo Park for several months while we build the permanent location, we will move TechShop to a temporary facility while we build out the permanent location.

The area we are focused on for the temporary location and the permanent location is somewhere within 5 miles of the current TechShop location, and extending a little bit north. Here is a map that shows the region in which we would like to move TechShop Menlo Park:
The requirements for the temporary building include the following:
<ul>
• Within 5 miles of TechShop Menlo Park (i.e. Menlo Park, Palo Alto, Redwood City, Stanford, San Mateo, Belmont, San Carlos)
• 8,000 to 12,000 square feet
• 10' to 14' clear height
<li>Safe parking for up to 40 cars
• Ideally slab concrete floor on ground floor. If a second floor, we will need an operable freight elevator
• Power: 400-800 amp service at 240V
Our general plan to move and rebuild TechShop Menlo Park is as follows:
<ul>
• Secure a temporary location nearby and get ready for move-in
• Move to the temporary location by October 31 with less than 2 days downtime
• Secure a permanent location and design and build it out, which will take about 5 months
• Move TechShop Menlo Park to its new permanent location
<hr/>
<span style=""font-size: 18pt
column5: >We Can't Do This Without Your Help!

column1: We are once again turning to you and the rest of our amazing community for help. We need to raise a minimum of $2.5 million to fund the new equipment and build-out costs, and we will raise the money through a combination of fun and exciting perks on Indiegogo, as well as $25,000 loans (not through Indiegogo...for more information about becoming a lender, please see the loan information on our web site <a href=""http://www.techshop.ws/new_tsmp_loans.html"" rel=""noopener nofollow"" style=""color: #0000ff
column2: target=""_blank"">here. The money from the Indiegogo campaign and the money from the loans will be used to build out the temporary facility and the new permanent facility, purchase all brand-new equipment, and put the whole thing together.  The new TechShop Menlo Park will be even more beautiful and amazing than any of the other TechShop locations we have built so far, and will incorporate all the new programs and machines that we have added to the TechShop core over the years.  This is a huge and ambitious project, and we could never do this without the support of you and the rest of our community!

column1: <hr/>
<span style=""font-size: 18pt
For this Indiegogo campaign, we are pulling out all the stops and offering some really crazy and cool perks that we hope will convince you to help us rebuild and move TechShop Menlo Park.
<table border=""0""><tbody><tr><td style=""padding-left: 25px
<table border=""1"" style=""padding-left: 25px
<tr><td style=""padding: 5px
Free TS Memberships for US Veterans

Your $25, $100, $1,000 or any amount you choose will go towards the purchase of annual TechShop memberships and classes for US Veterans through our ""Get Skills To Work"" program which we have developed with our partners General Electric, the US Department of Veterans Affairs, LinkedIn, Boeing, Lockheed Martin, Alcoa Aluminum, the Gary Sinise Foundation, and many others.
Help vets build skills to become great potential employees in the private sector, or to develop their own product or company.
You can buy as many as you want.
We will also include the laser-engraved wood, plastic, metal or fabric tile with your name on it on the TechShop Menlo Park Friends Wall if you choose this perk at the $100 level or more.

TechShop member and founder of Oru, Anton Willis, raised over $400,000 with his crowdfunding campaign. You can read more about this award winning product at <a href=""http://www.orukayak.com"" rel=""noopener nofollow"" style=""color: #0000ff

Like its predecessor, the Series 1 is designed as a platform and is ready for upgrades as new technologies emerge (or as your inspiration takes you), so your 3D printer investment will be as cutting edge tomorrow as it is today.

Jim Newton is Your Personal Dream Consultant for a Day

You can have Jim do pretty much anything you want on your project, and, like our regular DCs, he will be genuinely delighted to do it for you!
We will include the laser-engraved wood, plastic, metal or fabric tile with your name on it on the TechShop Menlo Park Friends Wall if you choose this perk.
