<span style=""font-size: 18pt
column5: >More About the ""Get Skills To Work"" Program

column1: One big way you can help fund TechShop Menlo Park's move and rebuilding is to contribute as much as you can to our ""Get Skills To Work"" program (you can read more about this in our <a href=""http://www.techshop.ws/veterans.html"" rel=""noopener nofollow"" style=""color: #0000ff

This fantastic program, which was created by TechShop and our other partners including General Electric, Boeing, LinkedIn, the Gary Sinise Foundation, Alcoa, Lockheed Martin, and many others, provides annual TechShop memberships along with TechShop classes to US Veterans who want to learn new job skills particularly in advanced manufacturing areas such as CNC machining, laser cutting, 3D printing, and computer aided design.  It also provides memberships and classes to veterans who want to explore being entrepreneurs in order to develop a new product, service, or company.
You can read more about the overall program at the <a href=""http://www.getskillstowork.org"" rel=""noopener nofollow"" style=""color: #0000ff
column2: target=""_blank"">Get Skills To Work web site.

column1: Here is a brief video of actor Gary Sinise, founder of the Gary Sinise Foundation and one of our partners in the ""Get Skills To Work"" program, talking about just how valuable the program is to veterans:
100% of the funds raised through the different ""Memberships for US Veterans"" perks in this ""TechShop Menlo Park: Move &amp
column2: Rebuild!"" Indiegogo campaign will be used to provide annual TechShop memberships and classes at absolutely no cost to US Veterans who apply, and the revenue will be applied to the TechShop Menlo Park moving and rebuilding effort. We have already distributed over 1,000 free memberships to veterans since we started the ""Get Skills To Work"" program a few months ago.

column1: Your contribution will help us provide more of these memberships and classes and help vets build skills to become great potential employees in the private sector, or to develop their own product or company.
<hr/>
<span style=""font-size: 18pt

We understand that some people just can't contribute financially, but that doesn't mean they can't still help us empower people with the new TechShop Menlo Park.  If you aren't able to help financially right now, here are a few ways that you can help us that don't require you to spend any money:
<ul>

• SPREAD THE WORD!!!  Let people know about this campaign through email, word-of-mouth, social networking, blogs, newspapers, and any other channels you can think of (you can also use the Indiegogo share tools)
• Let us know if you can volunteer to do construction, move stuff, paint walls, organize volunteers, or anything else you think we might need
• Introduce us to people who you think might want to become $25,000 lenders
• Let us know if there is a perk that you would love to get that we have not listed in this campaign yet!
<hr/>
<span style=""font-size: 18pt
column5: >The TechShop Menlo Park Move and Rebuild Team

column2: >We have built a fantastic team at TechShop, and every single person on our staff is dedicated to the TechShop mission of empowering people to be able to build the things they want to make.
>Here are some of our team members who are directly involved in the ""TechShop Menlo Park: Move &amp

column1: <table border=""0""><tbody><tr><td style=""padding-left: 25px
<table border=""1"" style=""background-color: #DDFFFF
<tr></tr>
<tr><td style=""padding: 5px
Jim is the founder of TechShop, and loves to make things.  He lives near TechShop Menlo Park, which is the real reason that he started the first TechShop in that area.
<tr><td style=""padding: 5px
Mark has a strong background in consumer-facing businesses including Kinko's.  He shares Jim's strong passion to empower everyone in the world with the tools of innovation.
<tr><td style=""padding: 5px
As the co-founder of Make in his previous job, Dan understands importance of the maker movement perhaps as well as anyone else.
<tr><td style=""padding: 5px
Mike started out at TechShop as the General Manager of TechShop Menlo Park, quickly proved himself able to open new TechShop locations.
<tr><td style=""padding-left: 5px
Carrie came to TechShop after working at Sun Microsystems, and has been a fantastic asset to TechShop in getting TechShop's message out to the community.
<tr><td style=""padding-left: 5px
Raffie started out as the GM for TechShop San Jose, and has now taken an expanded role as manager for TechShop Menlo Park as well.
<tr><td style=""padding-left: 5px
Sesame is one of our longest-term employees.  She is very enthusiastic about TechShop's mission, and will work with you if you are interested in being a lender or investor.
<span style=""font-size: 18pt
Here are some answers to some of the more common questions people have asked us about our project of moving and rebuilding TechShop Menlo Park:
<hr/>
<span style=""font-weight: bold
column4: >Q: When do you need to be out of the current location?

column1: <span style=""font-weight: bold

A: We must be completely out of the building by October 31, 2013. Our goal is to minimize interruption of service to our members and staff as much as possible. We will run classes until the last possible day in the current shop and resume them as soon as we can in the new location.
<hr/>
<span style=""font-weight: bold

Q: There are already 2 other TechShop locations in the Bay Area within 30 minutes of the TechShop Menlo Park location (TechShop San Francisco and TechShop San Jose). Would you consider moving TechShop Menlo Park to the East Bay or Newark or Santa Rosa or Las Vegas or Sunnyvale or Hawaii or Los Angeles instead of relocating it within 5 miles of the current location?
<span style=""font-weight: bold

A. TechShop Menlo Park currently has about 850 active paying members, thousands of people taking classes every month, and a full staff of amazing employees, so we feel it is the right thing to do to keep the new location within 5 miles of the current location.  TechShop Menlo Park members typically do not visit our other two Bay Area locations (TechShop San Francisco and TechShop San Jose), so this data indicates that we need to keep the temporary and new TechShop Menlo Park location in the same vicinity.  We wouldn't want to move TechShop Menlo Park to a location that is too close to TechShop San Francisco or TechShop San Jose.
<span style=""font-weight: bold
However, our goal is to build hundreds and even thousands of TechShop locations in the US and other countries, so it is highly likely that we will eventually build a TechShop in your city.
<span style=""font-weight: bold
column4: >You can help us get to your city faster by talking with the city leaders, organizations and companies, and raising interest and monetary commitments. We typically need $3.5 million to open a brand-new TechShop location in a given city, and this money can be in the form of large blocks of pre-paid memberships for a 5 or 10 year term, large corporate sponsorships, loans to the local TechShop location, and corporate strategic investments in TechShop corporate to be earmarked for the local TechShop location.

column1: <span style=""font-weight: bold
column4: >Donations of any amount can be made to our highly successful ""Get Skills To Work"" veteran's membership program which provides free annual memberships and free classes to veterans of all the military branches of the United States of America so they can develop advanced manufacturing skills to be better candidates for jobs, or to gain the skills to start their own businesses. You can find out more about TechShop's ""Get Skills To Work"" program with our partners General Electric, US Department of Veteran's Affairs, Boeing, Alcoa, LinkedIn, Lockheed Martin, US Chamber of Commerce, and many others, at <a href=""http://www.getskillstowork.org"" rel=""noopener nofollow"" style=""color: #0000ff

column1: <hr/>
<span style=""font-weight: bold
Q: How can I help fund or donate to TechShop Menlo Park to help with the move and rebuilding?
<span style=""font-weight: bold
A: Our Indiegogo campaign, which can be found at ""<a href=""http://igg.me/at/tsmp"" rel=""noopener nofollow"" style=""color: #0000ff
column2: >http://igg.me/at/tsmp"", is the best way to help.  You can also inquire about becoming a lender with $25,000 or more on our web site

column1: <hr/>
<span style=""font-weight: bold
Q: What is the timeline to build a permanent location and move in?
<span style=""font-weight: bold
A. It takes about 5 months to build out a full permanent TechShop facility based on the timelines of the additional 5 locations we have built out since we opened TechShop Menlo Park.
<hr/>
<span style=""font-weight: bold
Q. How can I loan you money to help with the move and rebuilding of TechShop Menlo Park?
<span style=""font-weight: bold
A. You can inquire about becoming a lender with $25,000 or more on our web site <a href=""http://www.techshop.ws/new_tsmp_loans.html"" rel=""noopener nofollow"" style=""color: #0000ff
<hr/>
<span style=""font-weight: bold
Q.  What will the new permanent TechShop Menlo Park look like, and what equipment and facilities will it have for me to use as a member?
<span style=""font-weight: bold
A. Our plan is to include all the latest programs and equipment that we have in our other newer TechShop locations, plus some new ones that will first appear at the new TechShop Menlo Park facility.
<hr/>
<span style=""font-weight: bold
Q.  What happens if you can't find a temporary space in time?
<span style=""font-weight: bold

A. Unfortunately, if we are not able to raise the required funding through the Indiegogo campaign and through loans from individuals, we will need to suspend activities at TechShop Menlo Park.  If this were to happen, we would ask current members of TechShop Menlo Park to use either TechShop San Francisco or TechShop San Jose.  We would also offer prorated refunds to members who requested them.  We are quite confident that you and the rest of the TechShop community will help us successfully raise the funds we need to move TechShop Menlo Park and rebuild it to be the best TechShop yet.
<hr/>
<span style=""font-weight: bold
Q.  Why is your Indiegogo campaign goal $250,000, but you say that you need $2.5 million in order to move and rebuild TechShop Menlo Park?
<span style=""font-weight: bold

A. We are raising our funding for moving and rebuilding TechShop Menlo Park from a combination of Indiegogo perks and $25,000 loans from individuals.  We really have no idea how many loans we will secure, and we don't know if we will overshoot or undershoot our Indiegogo goal.  So because of the sage advice from the folks at Indiegogo, we set the goal on our Indiegogo campaign of $250,000 assuming that we will either overshoot on the Indiegogo funding (which would be awesome), or we will be able to raise $2,250,000 in loans, which is 90 people lending us $25,000 each.  Our history supports this idea, as we raised over $5 million in $25,000 loans to open TechShop San Francisco and TechShop San Jose, so we know it is definitely possible to do this and the TechShop community will step up to the challenge.
<hr/>
<span style=""font-weight: bold
Q.  What happens if you don't raise the full $2.5 million (as a combination of Indiegogo perks and loans) by the end of this Indiegogo campaign?
<span style=""font-weight: bold

A. We are pretty confident that we will be able to reach our goal on Indiegogo, and reach our goal of bringing in loans from individuals, since we have done it so many times before with success.  However, if we don't reach our goal by the end of the Indiegogo campaign, we may need to extend our timeline, and there would be a chance that we would have to temporarily suspend operations at TechShop Menlo Park until we are able to raise all the money.  In this case, the equipment would be put into storage, and we would work on completing funding so we could start work on the temporary location and then on the permanent location.
<hr/>
<span style=""font-weight: bold
Q.  Why do you need $2.5 million to relocate and rebuild TechShop Menlo Park?  Could you do it for less?
<span style=""font-weight: bold

A. In our experience, it actually takes $3.5 million to build and open a TechShop location in a new city. TechShop San Francisco and TechShop San Jose ended up costing around that much, but because we raised $2.7 million, we had to do additional fundraising as we continued the build-outs. TechShop Menlo Park is already well-established and has a strong member base, and above all it has been profitable for some time.  Because of these factors, we can build TechShop Menlo Park for much less than it costs us to build a new TechShop in a given city.  Some of the money goes to the ""TIs"" or ""tenant improvements"" which is the build out of the walls and floors and ceilings, HVAC and ventilation systems, electrical, natural gas, water, drainage, air, networking, lighting, safety, signage, access control, and all the infrastructure items.  Some of the money goes to purchasing the new equipment and supporting supplies and fixtures and furnishings.  Some of the money goes to pay for items like tables and chairs, desks, appliances, the front desk, and other such items.  We make a lot of these items ourselves with TechShop equipment.  There is a lot more than immediately meets the eye that goes into a TechShop facility to make it a delightful place to ""build your dreams""!
<hr/>
<span style=""font-size: 18pt
column5: >Please Back This Campaign Right Now By Choosing As Many of the Perks as you Can!

column1: It is only with the generous support of you and everyone else in the TechShop community that we will be able to move and rebuild TechShop Menlo Park for everyone to enjoy.
<hr/>
<span style=""font-size: 18pt
column5: >From the Entire TechShop Family Including Our Members, Our staff, and Our Community...WE THANK YOU!!!

column1: ","Help Us Move and Rebuild the Original TechShop Menlo Park!

My name is Jim Newton, and I am the founder of TechShop. I started TechShop because I needed a place to build my hundreds of projects. It turned out that a lot of other people needed the same thing, and that's what has made TechShop such a success!

I started TechShop because I am a maker, and I personally needed access to a wide range of tools and equipment so I could build my hundreds of ideas. Originally I planned to only build one TechShop (this one in Menlo Park), but it turned out that the idea was a lot bigger than I had anticipated, so we quickly began to expand.
The land where our original location in Menlo Park is located is being redeveloped, so we have to move TechShop Menlo Park to a new location by Halloween 2013!

As part of the TechShop Menlo Park community, we ask you to consider backing this Indiegogo campaign in any way you can in order to help us raise $2.5 million so we can move TechShop Menlo Park, and rebuild it as the best TechShop location yet!
What Is TechShop?
TechShop is America's first and largest membership-based do-it-yourself workshop that empowers its members to build all the things they have always wanted to make.
Here is a brief video about TechShop and features a few of our members who use TechShop to make an impact on the world, and their own lives:
The First TechShop Ever...TechShop Menlo Park

I opened the first TechShop in Menlo Park back in October 2006, before there were any hackerspaces or makerspaces in the US. We couldn't just look at another makerspace and copy their model, so we had to design it from scratch. But with the help of our amazing community, we were able to fund it and get it open. Members of our community helped by telling everyone they knew about the TechShop idea, by pre-purchasing memberships, by providing us with $25,000 loans, and by volunteering to help us actually build the facility. As a result, we opened the doors of the very first TechShop on October 1, 2006...almost exactly 7 years ago.
As demand grew, we went on to build TechShop San Francisco and TechShop San Jose and crowd-funded more than $5 million for those two locations before there was even such a thing as ""crowd-funding"".

Today we have six TechShop locations across the US (TechShop Menlo Park, TechShop San Francisco, TechShop San Jose, TechShop Detroit, TechShop Austin, and TechShop Pittsburgh) and five more locations in development including TechShop Chandler AZ in partnership with Arizona State University, which will open in November 2013.
Our mission is to open hundreds of TechShop locations in the US and other countries and provide everyone with the tools of innovation so they can make amazing things and change the world.

We employ over 120 full-time employees, hundreds of part-time instructors, and we currently serve nearly 6,000 active members including 850 active members at TechShop Menlo Park. Thousands of people take classes at TechShop every month.

TechShop has enabled many of its members to launch businesses and products, including some world-changing products and a lot of very successful campaigns on Indiegogo and other crowd-funding platforms.

TechShop Menlo Park was our very first location...where it all started. I have a personal love for this beat-up old location, and lots of our members love it despite its blemishes. But now TechShop Menlo Park is in danger of being closed if we can't raise funding to move it to a new location.
We Have To Move or Close Down!

As part of a planned development that has been in the works for a while, our Menlo Park building along with all the other buildings on our block are now slated to be demolished.  So we need to move out of our current building before October 31, 2013...Halloween!
An Exciting and Positive Opportunity

We actually see this turn of events as a very positive opportunity for us to make TechShop Menlo Park even better than it is now and add all the new programs that the other TechShop members enjoy.  Yes, the situation is urgent, and if we can't raise the funding we need, then we will need to suspend operations of TechShop Menlo Park, but we are hopeful that you and the rest of the community will step forward and help us raise the money we need and move and rebuild TechShop Menlo Park!
So What's Our Big Plan?
We've learned a lot and made a lot of improvements in the TechShop model since we opened this first location back in 2006.

The new TechShop Menlo Park will feature all brand-new tools and equipment. Right now, TechShop Menlo Park still has a lot of the old used equipment that we started with, but it will all be replaced. If we meet our funding goals, we are going to try our best to add some exciting new program areas including a Flow water jet cutter just like we have in all our other locations, an expanded automotive area with a car lift, a licensed and certified commercial kitchen for member use along with a variety of new cooking classes, a jewelry studio complete with a vacuum metal casting foundry, an expanded electronics lab with all new equipment including LabView software and hardware, a large flex room that can be split into smaller rooms for large and small events and includes a back-of-house catering kitchen for food service at events, and lots more.

When we build a new TechShop location as we have in San Francisco, San Jose, Detroit, Austin, and Pittsburgh, it takes us about 5 months to design it, get permits, complete the construction, order all the new equipment, and install everything. We have a lot of experience with this now and we have gotten pretty good at it. We anticipate that the permanent new location facility for TechShop Menlo Park will also take about 5 months to build. The problem is that we have to be out of the current building long before then. So rather than shut down TechShop Menlo Park for several months while we build the permanent location, we will move TechShop to a temporary facility while we build out the permanent location.

The area we are focused on for the temporary location and the permanent location is somewhere within 5 miles of the current TechShop location, and extending a little bit north. Here is a map that shows the region in which we would like to move TechShop Menlo Park:
The requirements for the temporary building include the following:
Within 5 miles of TechShop Menlo Park (i.e. Menlo Park, Palo Alto, Redwood City, Stanford, San Mateo, Belmont, San Carlos)
8,000 to 12,000 square feet
10' to 14' clear height
Safe parking for up to 40 cars
Ideally slab concrete floor on ground floor. If a second floor, we will need an operable freight elevator
Power: 400-800 amp service at 240V
Our general plan to move and rebuild TechShop Menlo Park is as follows:
Secure a temporary location nearby and get ready for move-in
Move to the temporary location by October 31 with less than 2 days downtime
Secure a permanent location and design and build it out, which will take about 5 months
Move TechShop Menlo Park to its new permanent location
We Can't Do This Without Your Help!

We are once again turning to you and the rest of our amazing community for help. We need to raise a minimum of $2.5 million to fund the new equipment and build-out costs, and we will raise the money through a combination of fun and exciting perks on Indiegogo, as well as $25,000 loans (not through Indiegogo...for more information about becoming a lender, please see the loan information on our web site here. The money from the Indiegogo campaign and the money from the loans will be used to build out the temporary facility and the new permanent facility, purchase all brand-new equipment, and put the whole thing together.  The new TechShop Menlo Park will be even more beautiful and amazing than any of the other TechShop locations we have built so far, and will incorporate all the new programs and machines that we have added to the TechShop core over the years.  This is a huge and ambitious project, and we could never do this without the support of you and the rest of our community!
Check Out These Great Perks
For this Indiegogo campaign, we are pulling out all the stops and offering some really crazy and cool perks that we hope will convince you to help us rebuild and move TechShop Menlo Park.
Free TS Memberships for US Veterans

Your $25, $100, $1,000 or any amount you choose will go towards the purchase of annual TechShop memberships and classes for US Veterans through our ""Get Skills To Work"" program which we have developed with our partners General Electric, the US Department of Veterans Affairs, LinkedIn, Boeing, Lockheed Martin, Alcoa Aluminum, the Gary Sinise Foundation, and many others.
Help vets build skills to become great potential employees in the private sector, or to develop their own product or company.
You can buy as many as you want.

The next generation Type A Machines Series 1 3D Printer builds on the award winning original Series 1. Featuring a streamlined aluminum and acrylic body, a glass build surface, and updated electronics, the Series 1 is designed for reliability and maximum up-time. Like its predecessor, the Series 1 is designed as a platform and is ready for upgrades as new technologies emerge (or as your inspiration takes you), so your 3D printer investment will be as cutting edge tomorrow as it is today. typeamachines.com
Jim Newton is Your Personal Dream Consultant for a Day
Jim Newton, TechShop's founder, will be your personal Dream Consultant for a whole day, and you and Jim will work on your project together.
You can have Jim do pretty much anything you want on your project, and, like our regular DCs, he will be genuinely delighted to do it for you!
We will include the laser-engraved wood, plastic, metal or fabric tile with your name on it on the TechShop Menlo Park Friends Wall if you choose this perk.
More About the ""Get Skills To Work"" Program
One big way you can help fund TechShop Menlo Park's move and rebuilding is to contribute as much as you can to our ""Get Skills To Work"" program (you can read more about this in our Veterans page.

This fantastic program, which was created by TechShop and our other partners including General Electric, Boeing, LinkedIn, the Gary Sinise Foundation, Alcoa, Lockheed Martin, and many others, provides annual TechShop memberships along with TechShop classes to US Veterans who want to learn new job skills particularly in advanced manufacturing areas such as CNC machining, laser cutting, 3D printing, and computer aided design.  It also provides memberships and classes to veterans who want to explore being entrepreneurs in order to develop a new product, service, or company.
You can read more about the overall program at the Get Skills To Work web site.

Here is a brief video of actor Gary Sinise, founder of the Gary Sinise Foundation and one of our partners in the ""Get Skills To Work"" program, talking about just how valuable the program is to veterans:

100% of the funds raised through the different ""Memberships for US Veterans"" perks in this ""TechShop Menlo Park: Move & Rebuild!"" Indiegogo campaign will be used to provide annual TechShop memberships and classes at absolutely no cost to US Veterans who apply, and the revenue will be applied to the TechShop Menlo Park moving and rebuilding effort. We have already distributed over 1,000 free memberships to veterans since we started the ""Get Skills To Work"" program a few months ago.

Your contribution will help us provide more of these memberships and classes and help vets build skills to become great potential employees in the private sector, or to develop their own product or company.
Other Ways You Can Help

We understand that some people just can't contribute financially, but that doesn't mean they can't still help us empower people with the new TechShop Menlo Park.  If you aren't able to help financially right now, here are a few ways that you can help us that don't require you to spend any money:

SPREAD THE WORD!!!  Let people know about this campaign through email, word-of-mouth, social networking, blogs, newspapers, and any other channels you can think of (you can also use the Indiegogo share tools)
Let us know if you can volunteer to do construction, move stuff, paint walls, organize volunteers, or anything else you think we might need
Introduce us to people who you think might want to become $25,000 lenders
Let us know if there is a perk that you would love to get that we have not listed in this campaign yet!
The TechShop Menlo Park Move and Rebuild Team
We have built a fantastic team at TechShop, and every single person on our staff is dedicated to the TechShop mission of empowering people to be able to build the things they want to make.
Here are some of our team members who are directly involved in the ""TechShop Menlo Park: Move & Rebuild!"" project:
Jim NewtonFounder and Chairman
Jim is the founder of TechShop, and loves to make things.  He lives near TechShop Menlo Park, which is the real reason that he started the first TechShop in that area.
Mark HatchCEO and Co-Founder
Mark has a strong background in consumer-facing businesses including Kinko's.  He shares Jim's strong passion to empower everyone in the world with the tools of innovation.
Dan WoodsCOO
As the co-founder of Make in his previous job, Dan understands importance of the maker movement perhaps as well as anyone else.
Mike CatterlinManaging Director of Operations
Mike started out at TechShop as the General Manager of TechShop Menlo Park, quickly proved himself able to open new TechShop locations.
Carrie MotamediVP of Marketing and PR
Carrie came to TechShop after working at Sun Microsystems, and has been a fantastic asset to TechShop in getting TechShop's message out to the community.
Raffie ColetGeneral Manager for TechShop Menlo Park
Raffie started out as the GM for TechShop San Jose, and has now taken an expanded role as manager for TechShop Menlo Park as well.
Sesame MishInvestor Relations Manager
Sesame is one of our longest-term employees.  She is very enthusiastic about TechShop's mission, and will work with you if you are interested in being a lender or investor.
Frequently Asked Questions
Here are some answers to some of the more common questions people have asked us about our project of moving and rebuilding TechShop Menlo Park:
Q: When do you need to be out of the current location?

A: We must be completely out of the building by October 31, 2013. Our goal is to minimize interruption of service to our members and staff as much as possible. We will run classes until the last possible day in the current shop and resume them as soon as we can in the new location.

Q: There are already 2 other TechShop locations in the Bay Area within 30 minutes of the TechShop Menlo Park location (TechShop San Francisco and TechShop San Jose). Would you consider moving TechShop Menlo Park to the East Bay or Newark or Santa Rosa or Las Vegas or Sunnyvale or Hawaii or Los Angeles instead of relocating it within 5 miles of the current location?

A. TechShop Menlo Park currently has about 850 active paying members, thousands of people taking classes every month, and a full staff of amazing employees, so we feel it is the right thing to do to keep the new location within 5 miles of the current location.  TechShop Menlo Park members typically do not visit our other two Bay Area locations (TechShop San Francisco and TechShop San Jose), so this data indicates that we need to keep the temporary and new TechShop Menlo Park location in the same vicinity.  We wouldn't want to move TechShop Menlo Park to a location that is too close to TechShop San Francisco or TechShop San Jose.
However, our goal is to build hundreds and even thousands of TechShop locations in the US and other countries, so it is highly likely that we will eventually build a TechShop in your city.

You can help us get to your city faster by talking with the city leaders, organizations and companies, and raising interest and monetary commitments. We typically need $3.5 million to open a brand-new TechShop location in a given city, and this money can be in the form of large blocks of pre-paid memberships for a 5 or 10 year term, large corporate sponsorships, loans to the local TechShop location, and corporate strategic investments in TechShop corporate to be earmarked for the local TechShop location.

Donations of any amount can be made to our highly successful ""Get Skills To Work"" veteran's membership program which provides free annual memberships and free classes to veterans of all the military branches of the United States of America so they can develop advanced manufacturing skills to be better candidates for jobs, or to gain the skills to start their own businesses. You can find out more about TechShop's ""Get Skills To Work"" program with our partners General Electric, US Department of Veteran's Affairs, Boeing, Alcoa, LinkedIn, Lockheed Martin, US Chamber of Commerce, and many others, at http://www.getskillstowork.org.
Q: How can I help fund or donate to TechShop Menlo Park to help with the move and rebuilding?
A: Our Indiegogo campaign, which can be found at ""http://igg.me/at/tsmp"", is the best way to help.  You can also inquire about becoming a lender with $25,000 or more on our web site here.
Q: What is the timeline to build a permanent location and move in?
A. It takes about 5 months to build out a full permanent TechShop facility based on the timelines of the additional 5 locations we have built out since we opened TechShop Menlo Park.
Q. How can I loan you money to help with the move and rebuilding of TechShop Menlo Park?
A. You can inquire about becoming a lender with $25,000 or more on our web site here.
Q.  What will the new permanent TechShop Menlo Park look like, and what equipment and facilities will it have for me to use as a member?
A. Our plan is to include all the latest programs and equipment that we have in our other newer TechShop locations, plus some new ones that will first appear at the new TechShop Menlo Park facility.
Q.  What happens if you can't find a temporary space in time?

A. Unfortunately, if we are not able to raise the required funding through the Indiegogo campaign and through loans from individuals, we will need to suspend activities at TechShop Menlo Park.  If this were to happen, we would ask current members of TechShop Menlo Park to use either TechShop San Francisco or TechShop San Jose.  We would also offer prorated refunds to members who requested them.  We are quite confident that you and the rest of the TechShop community will help us successfully raise the funds we need to move TechShop Menlo Park and rebuild it to be the best TechShop yet.
Q.  Why is your Indiegogo campaign goal $250,000, but you say that you need $2.5 million in order to move and rebuild TechShop Menlo Park?

A. We are raising our funding for moving and rebuilding TechShop Menlo Park from a combination of Indiegogo perks and $25,000 loans from individuals.  We really have no idea how many loans we will secure, and we don't know if we will overshoot or undershoot our Indiegogo goal.  So because of the sage advice from the folks at Indiegogo, we set the goal on our Indiegogo campaign of $250,000 assuming that we will either overshoot on the Indiegogo funding (which would be awesome), or we will be able to raise $2,250,000 in loans, which is 90 people lending us $25,000 each.  Our history supports this idea, as we raised over $5 million in $25,000 loans to open TechShop San Francisco and TechShop San Jose, so we know it is definitely possible to do this and the TechShop community will step up to the challenge.
Q.  What happens if you don't raise the full $2.5 million (as a combination of Indiegogo perks and loans) by the end of this Indiegogo campaign?

A. We are pretty confident that we will be able to reach our goal on Indiegogo, and reach our goal of bringing in loans from individuals, since we have done it so many times before with success.  However, if we don't reach our goal by the end of the Indiegogo campaign, we may need to extend our timeline, and there would be a chance that we would have to temporarily suspend operations at TechShop Menlo Park until we are able to raise all the money.  In this case, the equipment would be put into storage, and we would work on completing funding so we could start work on the temporary location and then on the permanent location.
Q.  Why do you need $2.5 million to relocate and rebuild TechShop Menlo Park?  Could you do it for less?

A. In our experience, it actually takes $3.5 million to build and open a TechShop location in a new city. TechShop San Francisco and TechShop San Jose ended up costing around that much, but because we raised $2.7 million, we had to do additional fundraising as we continued the build-outs. TechShop Menlo Park is already well-established and has a strong member base, and above all it has been profitable for some time.  Because of these factors, we can build TechShop Menlo Park for much less than it costs us to build a new TechShop in a given city.  Some of the money goes to the ""TIs"" or ""tenant improvements"" which is the build out of the walls and floors and ceilings, HVAC and ventilation systems, electrical, natural gas, water, drainage, air, networking, lighting, safety, signage, access control, and all the infrastructure items.  Some of the money goes to purchasing the new equipment and supporting supplies and fixtures and furnishings.  Some of the money goes to pay for items like tables and chairs, desks, appliances, the front desk, and other such items.  We make a lot of these items ourselves with TechShop equipment.  There is a lot more than immediately meets the eye that goes into a TechShop facility to make it a delightful place to ""build your dreams""!
Please Back This Campaign Right Now By Choosing As Many of the Perks as you Can!
It is only with the generous support of you and everyone else in the TechShop community that we will be able to move and rebuild TechShop Menlo Park for everyone to enjoy.
From the Entire TechShop Family Including Our Members, Our staff, and Our Community...WE THANK YOU!!!",20.0,2,"2 Campaigns

Our Way Forward

On Sunday, August 11th, 2013, a tragic hit and run accident took the lives of Elle Walters and Ty Salistein. Three children mourn the loss of their parents, mother of Savannah Walters, Joseph Walters and father to Trey Salistein. Savannah, has a life threatening blood disorder which requires continual blood transfusions and other necessary medical procedures on a regular basis. A group of friends and family along with the owners in the Martini Corner District, has coordinated a fundraiser for the kids the weekend of October 12th, 2013.
<ul>

• Our Way Forward was founded by a group of Elle and Ty's family and friends. We share the same wish to honor Elle and Ty by providing a fund for their children so that they may move forward in their lives.
• This campaign is based upon the giving and selfless nature that both Elle and Ty embraced. All the members in our group were in one way or another touched by their generosity.
• We realize that many of you were recipients of their caring nature so we hope that by your donation you too will be able to honor them.
<h3>Funding &amp
<ul>

• Our goal of $25,000 will directly benefit the children: Savannah, Joseph, and Trey. Funds will enable the children to continue their everyday lives and support any needs they may have such as activity fees, education, clothing, and medical costs.

• Additional donations can be made to any Wells Fargo Bank:
    • Attention: ""Our Way Forward Memorial Fund""
The Impact
<ul>

• Ongoing medical costs are a reality in Savannah's life. She has a life long illness called Beta Thalassemia Major. Also known as Cooley's Anemia. There is no cure for her at this time and she requires chronic blood transfusions to survive. She gets transfused every three weeks, along with two other treatments she gets done on a consistent basis. Savannah requires a visit to see a doctor in California every year to asses her health and make sure her iron levels are normal and not an immediate danger to her health.

• Joseph is a High School senior this year.  We would like to ensure that he has the necessities of a senior such as senior photos, yearbook, and class ring among other things.  And of course we want to help facilitate the road to his college career.
• Trey is 11 years old and has many adventures ahead of him.  With funding, he can make future memories in whatever he chooses to do.
Other Ways You Can Help
<ul>
<li>
http://www.ourwayforward.net/
<li>
<li><span style=""font-family: 'Open Sans'

Interactive City – who we are

Interactive City is an independent project founded in collaboration with researchers and architects from the UK, Russia and Eastern Europe. Interactive City will organise a series of workshops and schools for young researchers, architects, planners and professionals in cities in Russia and Eastern Europe. The aim?
<ul>
<li>
Develop knowledge of the process of urban change and to engage participants in a critical appraisal of the city
<li>
Intervene in the development of the city to re-define the way in which it is used and perceived by citizens, business and government
<li>
Create a more just and inclusive city through education, interaction and engagement the urban population

Interactive City builds upon previous collaborative projects focused on the post-socialist city which have involved the successful organisation of a series of workshops in 2010 and 2011 in St Petersburg, Moscow, Venice and London. You can view the programme for Post-socialist Moscow 2011 here.
Interactive Moscow – 2012 intervention

Moscow today is flooded by speculative developments. These developments exploit the legacy of the soviet planning system, not to benefit the state, but to profit a small social minority, while infringing the civil rights of the majority. Little or no attention is paid to the impact of these ill-considered developments on the city and its citizens. Civil society in Moscow has not yet evolved to understand and influence its role in this process.

Without collective action that engages and educates specialists and non-specialists, citizens and government, it will not be possible to change the course of development in Moscow. This is why Interactive City has chosen Moscow as the site of its 2012 intervention.
From 4 to 15 July, Interactive City will hold a summer school at the Strelka Institute in Moscow for undergraduates in a wide variety of fields. It is this summer school that you would help to fund.

The 10-day school will be organised around core lectures in urban theory, group discussions and site visits, culminating in an exhibition of the students’ proposals for an installation or other intervention to be placed in the city. You can read more about the programme for the school here.

The Interactive Moscow academic staff members are affiliated with leading institutions in the UK, Russia and Eastern Europe. You can read more about our academic staff and their other projects and publications here.
Where your money is going

Our target amount of $6,000 is the amount we will need to cover the anticipated expenses of Interactive Moscow and all money donated will go towards meeting those expenses. You can see a break-down of budgeted expenses below.
Travel to Moscow (UK-based academic staff)                $1,500,
Russian visas (UK-based academic staff)                     $1,000
Accommodation in Moscow (UK-based academic staff)   $2,000
Printing (promotional materials / exhibition)                $1,500

Our academic and administrative staff is fully committed to Interactive Moscow and interest from participants is building fast. Your contributions will be a highly important source of funds for Interactive Moscow. It seems to us that funding which engages a variety of people is an ideal source of funding for a project committed to an interactive, interdisciplinary approach and innovative forms of communication.
Whether you are interested in signing up for one of our Perks or making an independent contribution in an amount appropriate to you, your support will be greatly appreciated.
Other ways to support Interactive City

Whether or not you can make a financial contribution, your help in spreading the word about Interactive City and this campaign will be hugely appreciated. The number of people we reach will have a direct impact on our ability to fund Interactive Moscow, as well as the success of future Interactive City projects. So if you have friends or networks that you think might be interested in Interactive City and this campaign – please use the share tools to spread the word!

We will update this campaign profile with key milestones reached and details of the programme and participants, so please do keep coming back. Updates will also appear on the Interactive Moscow Website and the Interactive City group page on Facebook.

Short Summary

Six years ago, a group of youth and adults from the First United Methodist Church of Alachua, Florida traveled to the Harvest Deaf Bible College in Ringgold, Georgia for a mission trip. It was there that our passion for serving the deaf community was born, but we weren’t sure where that passion would lead us. The following summer, we embarked on our first international mission trip to the Dominican Republic. We ran a series of medical clinics in some of the poorest neighborhoods of Santo Domingo. One of the clinics was held at a church that also housed a school for deaf children founded by an American missionary. The youth on our trip immediately bonded with the children from the school and spent the afternoon doing what kids do -- playing chess, checkers, and cards –- just having fun. Even though at that time none of us knew sign language, we soon learned that love and laughter knew no language barriers. Later in the week, we took all the children from the school to an interactive science museum in the city. Watching the children explore the different interactive displays was such an amazing experience: they were so excited! Seeing little things bring them so much joy inspired us to want to do something more for these children, but we still weren’t sure what.
Later that year, the vision started to become clear – we wanted to host a summer camp for all of the children from the school
column2: and in June of 2009 we held our inaugural summer camp, Camp Hands of Joy. Since then we have traveled to the Dominican Republic every summer to host summer camp for the children. Our team has grown from our original 12 volunteers to about 30 American team members, including other volunteers from our local community. A group of students, alumni and affiliates of Rochester Institute of Technology’s ASL-English Interpretation Program in Rochester, New York have also joined the team. Numerous native Dominican volunteers have also partnered with us to help run the camp. Over time, more than half of our team members have become proficient at sign language as a second language. The group of Dominican children attending Camp Hands of Joy has grown from about 40 children in 2009 to over 80 children in 2012.

column1: During the week, the children receive 3 nutritious meals a day and enjoy fun, supervised camp activities including games, sports, crafts, drama and swimming. In addition, morning and evening chapel services and a small group discussion session are held each day. The camp facilities in the Dominican Republic are extremely primitive, but to these children, many of whom have live in appalling conditions, it is like a 5-star hotel. They feel safe and loved, and have an opportunity to just be a child.

As you can imagine, there are costs involved in organizing and running a week-long camp in a different part of the world for over a hundred participants. Without fundraising efforts like this one, it would be impossible for us to continue year after year. Your generous contribution will allow us to continue putting on this camp and bring a special joy to these children’s lives.
What We Need
Each year, the camp costs approximately $25,000 to put on. The costs are broken down as follows*:
<ul>
• Travel costs for the team - $700 per member (total cost varies depending on the number of volunteer team members)
• Room and board at camp (including food) - $50 per person, including volunteer team members, children and teaching staff
• Bus transportation for the children from their school in Santo Domingo to camp and back to the school again - $1,000
• Camp Supplies - $1,000
*Amounts are estimates and vary slightly from year to year.

Most of the families of the deaf Dominican children could not afford to provide a week-long camp experience of this nature for their child, so it is generous sponsorships and volunteer staffing that make Camp Hands of Joy possible. Will you please consider joining with us this year as we make June 16th- June 22nd, 2013, a very special week for the children? Without you, Camp Hands of Joy would not exist. No donation is too small.
The Impact

In the Dominican Republic deafness is looked upon as a disease and most children born deaf are not accepted in their families or their communities. The public school system is unable to deal with the specialized language needs of deaf children, so they are often lumped with mentally disabled children and labeled ""unable to learn"" even though many of them are incredibly intelligent and capable. Many deaf children do not learn any language, even things as basic as their own name, until age 9 or 10. Their families do not make the effort to learn sign language, so the children often lack any form of communication in their homes. For the most part, they are ignored and abused and are often left feeling isolated and alone. While there have been some efforts made by government, a few international agencies, and religious ministries to help educate deaf children, they are still left with little access to the everyday activities and fun which are common to other children their age.

About 10 years ago, an American Missionary, Peggy Blevins, started a small school in the capital city of Santo Domingo to help the deaf children in that area. Today, the school is in operation and currently has a waiting list of several children who are hoping to leave their life of isolation and enter a world where their potential can be realized. The school starts by giving the children a language, American Sign Language, which makes it possible for them to communicate. This basic fundamental skill provides opportunities they have never had before. Once the children learn sign language, their school experience is a typical one, learning reading and writing, Spanish and math. Most importantly, the teachers share with the children God's love that transcends whatever troubles they encounter in their lives.

The school has made an amazing impact on the deaf children of Santo Domingo, but there are limitations to the things that can be taught in a classroom environment. Children need to play and interact in a healthy, outdoor environment rich with teachable moments. Camp Hands of Joy provides that environment and is a wonderful compliment to the school. The children have the opportunity to not only spend a fun week with their friends from the deaf school, but also with deaf adult role models, and hearing people who know and love their language and are actively engaged in communicating with them. Over the past 5 years we have watched what once were shy, awkward, insecure children become loving, confident, self-sufficient individuals. It’s easy to see the impact Camp Hands of Joy makes on the children. We see it in their excited faces as they return to camp each summer, and in their tears as they say “until next year” to their American friends at the end of the week and return to their homes – confident that they are loved.
","Short Summary

Six years ago, a group of youth and adults from the First United Methodist Church of Alachua, Florida traveled to the Harvest Deaf Bible College in Ringgold, Georgia for a mission trip. It was there that our passion for serving the deaf community was born, but we weren’t sure where that passion would lead us. The following summer, we embarked on our first international mission trip to the Dominican Republic. We ran a series of medical clinics in some of the poorest neighborhoods of Santo Domingo. One of the clinics was held at a church that also housed a school for deaf children founded by an American missionary. The youth on our trip immediately bonded with the children from the school and spent the afternoon doing what kids do -- playing chess, checkers, and cards –- just having fun. Even though at that time none of us knew sign language, we soon learned that love and laughter knew no language barriers. Later in the week, we took all the children from the school to an interactive science museum in the city. Watching the children explore the different interactive displays was such an amazing experience: they were so excited! Seeing little things bring them so much joy inspired us to want to do something more for these children, but we still weren’t sure what.
Later that year, the vision started to become clear – we wanted to host a summer camp for all of the children from the school
column2: and in June of 2009 we held our inaugural summer camp, Camp Hands of Joy. Since then we have traveled to the Dominican Republic every summer to host summer camp for the children. Our team has grown from our original 12 volunteers to about 30 American team members, including other volunteers from our local community. A group of students, alumni and affiliates of Rochester Institute of Technology’s ASL-English Interpretation Program in Rochester, New York have also joined the team. Numerous native Dominican volunteers have also partnered with us to help run the camp. Over time, more than half of our team members have become proficient at sign language as a second language. The group of Dominican children attending Camp Hands of Joy has grown from about 40 children in 2009 to over 80 children in 2012.

column1: During the week, the children receive 3 nutritious meals a day and enjoy fun, supervised camp activities including games, sports, crafts, drama and swimming. In addition, morning and evening chapel services and a small group discussion session are held each day. The camp facilities in the Dominican Republic are extremely primitive, but to these children, many of whom have live in appalling conditions, it is like a 5-star hotel. They feel safe and loved, and have an opportunity to just be a child.

As you can imagine, there are costs involved in organizing and running a week-long camp in a different part of the world for over a hundred participants. Without fundraising efforts like this one, it would be impossible for us to continue year after year. Your generous contribution will allow us to continue putting on this camp and bring a special joy to these children’s lives.
What We Need
Each year, the camp costs approximately $25,000 to put on. The costs are broken down as follows*:
Travel costs for the team - $700 per member (total cost varies depending on the number of volunteer team members)
Room and board at camp (including food) - $50 per person, including volunteer team members, children and teaching staff
Bus transportation for the children from their school in Santo Domingo to camp and back to the school again - $1,000
Camp Supplies - $1,000
*Amounts are estimates and vary slightly from year to year.

Most of the families of the deaf Dominican children could not afford to provide a week-long camp experience of this nature for their child, so it is generous sponsorships and volunteer staffing that make Camp Hands of Joy possible. Will you please consider joining with us this year as we make June 16th- June 22nd, 2013, a very special week for the children? Without you, Camp Hands of Joy would not exist. No donation is too small.
The Impact

In the Dominican Republic deafness is looked upon as a disease and most children born deaf are not accepted in their families or their communities. The public school system is unable to deal with the specialized language needs of deaf children, so they are often lumped with mentally disabled children and labeled ""unable to learn"" even though many of them are incredibly intelligent and capable. Many deaf children do not learn any language, even things as basic as their own name, until age 9 or 10. Their families do not make the effort to learn sign language, so the children often lack any form of communication in their homes. For the most part, they are ignored and abused and are often left feeling isolated and alone. While there have been some efforts made by government, a few international agencies, and religious ministries to help educate deaf children, they are still left with little access to the everyday activities and fun which are common to other children their age.

About 10 years ago, an American Missionary, Peggy Blevins, started a small school in the capital city of Santo Domingo to help the deaf children in that area. Today, the school is in operation and currently has a waiting list of several children who are hoping to leave their life of isolation and enter a world where their potential can be realized. The school starts by giving the children a language, American Sign Language, which makes it possible for them to communicate. This basic fundamental skill provides opportunities they have never had before. Once the children learn sign language, their school experience is a typical one, learning reading and writing, Spanish and math. Most importantly, the teachers share with the children God's love that transcends whatever troubles they encounter in their lives.

The school has made an amazing impact on the deaf children of Santo Domingo, but there are limitations to the things that can be taught in a classroom environment. Children need to play and interact in a healthy, outdoor environment rich with teachable moments. Camp Hands of Joy provides that environment and is a wonderful compliment to the school. The children have the opportunity to not only spend a fun week with their friends from the deaf school, but also with deaf adult role models, and hearing people who know and love their language and are actively engaged in communicating with them. Over the past 5 years we have watched what once were shy, awkward, insecure children become loving, confident, self-sufficient individuals. It’s easy to see the impact Camp Hands of Joy makes on the children. We see it in their excited faces as they return to camp each summer, and in their tears as they say “until next year” to their American friends at the end of the week and return to their homes – confident that they are loved.",0.0,0,"1 Campaign
|","Alachua, United States",https://www.indiegogo.com/projects/camp-hands-of-joy-2013/pica

What is Muckraker, Inc.?

Muckraker, Inc. is a communications company founded by a group of citizen journalists. We’re just ordinary people fed up with the mainstream media’s ""business as usual."" We've dedicated ourselves to exposing corruption, giving a voice to the voiceless, being the source that whistle-blowers can truly trust, and elevating culture and the arts. Muckraker has founded several successful media outlets already, including Independent Gazette newspapers in Wilkes-Barre and Scranton, PA, and Trenton, NJ, and the radio show Sanity Check. The topics we’re addressing—everything from corruption in the family court system to exemplary small businesses and up-and-coming artists—are not relegated to one small region.

That’s why we want to expand. We plan to grow our media presence across the country, from the already-receptive Carolinas and Texas and then out to all other states. Our first target is the Poconos in Northeastern PA, and then, the World! Or, you know, maybe San Antonio.

Your contribution will help us to launch our next print edition in the Poconos, which will cover both Monroe and Pike counties. The money we raise will go directly toward printing and distribution costs, keeping Sanity Check on the air, and purchasing necessary equipment. 

We give everyone the chance to be heard by publishing voices otherwise marginalized by ""establishment"" media. By taking charge of your message through our media platform, you participate in your own freedom. Stand with us today, and help bring the spirit of a free press to the Poconos and beyond. We need your support to make it happen.
column2:
>  

What We Need &
column3:
What You Get

In order to launch the Independent Gazette in the Poconos and expand our existing publications, we need to meet the costs of printing and distribution for the printed paper, purchase video equipment for covering and posting events to the online paper, fund an increase in both publication frequency and overall volume for our Scranton, Wilkes-Barre, and Trenton papers, and secure studio time for our Sanity Check broadcasts. Our goal is to fund the basic necessities of running these outlets for a year. The costs include:

column1: • $14,400 in start-up printing costs for the Pocono IG
• $8,000 for curbside distribution boxes
• $2,600 for audio and video equipment
• $13,500 to expand our existing editions
<li><span style=""line-height: 1.45em

column3:
/>


In return for your generous contribution, we're offering some exciting perks!  

At the $10 level, you'll receive a personal ""thank you"" via email from the Muckraker staff, inclusion as a contributor on our family of websites, including the Pocono IG, Scranton/Wilkes-Barre IG, and Muckraker News sites, and one of both Muckraker pins shown below.

At the $25 level, you'll receive the previous perks, as well as the first issue of the Pocono Independent Gazette in the mail and an exclusive ""Cooking with Blake"" eBook. Created by chef Blake Belleman, it includes several favorites from his ""Cooking with Blake"" column, as well as other exclusive recipes, all found only in this eBook.

At the $50 level, you'll receive all previous perks, as well as a high-quality Muckraker T-shirt.

At the $100 level, you'll receive all previous perks, as well as a one-year subscription to both the Wilkes-Barre and Scranton editions of the Independent Gazette in the mail, plus a personal shout-out from host Lou on Sanity Check.

At the $100 level, you also have the option of a quarter page (4.5"" x 7.5"") grayscale ad in the Wilkes-Bare, Scranton, and Pocono papers, as well as on our family of websites—for either your business, or the charity, organization, or cause of your choice. You will also receive all previous perks, including a personal shout-out from host Lou on Sanity Check. You'll also receive all $10-$50 perks.

At the $250 level, you'll receive all $10-$50 perks, as well as a half page (9.5"" x 7.5"") grayscale ad in the Wilkes-Barre, Scranton, and Pocono papers, as well as on our family of websites, for either your business, or the charity, organization, or cause of your choice.

At the $500 level, you'll receive all $10-$50 perks, as well as a full page (9.5"" x 15.5"") grayscale ad in the Wilkes-Bare, Scranton, and Pocono papers, as well as on our family of websites, for either your business, or the charity, organization, or cause of your choice. 

At the $1,000 level, you'll receive all $10-$50 perks, as well as a full page (9.5"" x 15.5"") color ad in the Wilkes-Barre, Scranton, and Pocono editions of the Independent Gazette, as well as on our family of sites, for either your business, or the charity, organization, or cause of your choice. Also, we will write a business spotlight for the charity, organization, or cause of your choice to be featured in the paper.

At the $2,500 level, you'll receive all $10-$50 perks, as well as six months of half-page (9.5"" x 7.5"") color ads in the Wilkes-Barre, Scranton, and Pocono editions of the Independent Gazette, as well as on our family of sites, for either your business, or the charity, organization, or cause of your choice. Plus, we'll write a business spotlight for the charity, organization, or cause of your choice to be featured in the paper. Also, you will have the opportunity to co-host an episode of Sanity Check along with hosts Mike and Lou.

At the $5,000 level, you'll receive all $10-$50 perks, as well as six months of half-page (9.5"" x 7.5"") color ads in the Wilkes-Barre, Scranton, and Pocono editions of the Independent Gazette, as well as on our family of sites, for either your business, or the charity, organization, or cause of your choice. Plus, we will write a business spotlight for the charity, organization, or cause of your choice to be featured in the paper. Also, you will have the opportunity to co-host an episode of Sanity Check along with hosts Mike and Lou.

The Impact

Here at Muckraker, we feel that it is our duty to find and report the truth, no matter the push back from powerful special interest groups. Recently, we began reporting broken on horrible abuses within the family court system of Lackawana and Luzerne Counties in PA (and have included testimonials from around the country), doing our best to bring the corruption to light and to fight for the rights of both children and their parents. While these injustices appear to have been going on for years, the press had remained silent—until we broke the story.

In addition, the 2014 election cycle is upon us, and we're committed to bringing you the information you need to make informed decisions at the ballot box. By launching a new print edition and expanding our current outlets, we'll be better equipped to give you the information you need when you need it through fair, honest coverage of the candidates.

   

Other Ways You Can Help

Times are tough, and if you aren't able to help out financially right now, we understand.  But spreading the word is free! Feel free to share our campaign via the links below, or email this page to friends and family.

Hi,
column2: >It's Chas. I'm excited to have just been accepted into
column5: side=tv"" rel=""noopener nofollow"" target=""_blank""> UCLA's Professional Program for Writing in Television.
column6:
> Classes begin March 31st and I need help raising $4,000 for tuition. All donations are going soley to tuition and if my goal is surpassed funds will be used for textbooks. 

I've been writing all my life. My Bachelor of Arts degree is in Cinema Television Arts and I'm so excited to pursue a grad-level education at UCLA this Spring. I've written for web series, and performed on FX &
column7:
TVOne. I've also worked as a Teaching Aritst for the last 5 years for K-12.

If each person donates just $5 I know I'll reach my goal of $4,000 (of course if you can donate more, I ain't mad at you). 

Also, please share this campaign through your social media, email list, and word of mouth. 

I've only come this far because of a strong invested community so please rally around this and help me get to UCLA. 

Thank you,

Chas

Our Story

At enke we give youth a chance to realise their value, thrive and lead the change they wish to see for themselves, their communities and the world.  

South Africa has the worst youth unemployment rate in the world.  Our work was born from the need to uplift and equip youth with social, emotional and entrepreneurial skills needed to transform South Africa into a more equal and prosperous nation. 

enke means “ink” in SeTswana and “grab it” in SeSotho. That’s what we’re about – empowering youth to be authors of their futures by leading change in their lives and communities (making their mark). 

 

Our Impact

We connect, equip and inspire young people to make positive change, both in their own lives and the in lives of their communities.
column3:
/>

What We Need

We need your help to accelerate the growth and impact of our programs which build self-belief and resilience in youths with training, practical experience and inspiration.

The funds raised will be used to:

column1: • Extend our Catalyst Program, which is set out to contribute to reducing the unemployment rate.
• Build an online platform and web application for enke Program Alumni and other Youth to access information, resources and training to catalyse their social impact and entrepreneurship.
• Hold a conference to build collaboration and share knowledge and resources in the youth development sector.

Why This Is Important

The odds are stacked against youth in South Africa:
<li>55% are unemployed
<li>Nearly 8 million are not currently engaged in education or employment
<li>72% live on less that R30 ($2) a day
• 22% do not have access to resources that can help them find employment

We engage and equip the youth of South Africa to be the solution to the challenges they face as an individual and within their community.

We want all youth to have the networks, entrepreneurial skills and inspiration necessary to realise their value and thrive.

One way we do this is through our Catalyst Program.

 

Our programs and services empower and support young people to create meaningful change on the issues they care most about, whilst developing their own skills. 

 

We train and inspire young people, aged 15-30 years, to develop innovative solutions to create and achieve a positive future for themselves and their communities.

 

For more information about our programs and for our contact details visit https://enke.co.za/

For the second year in a row, the Baker High School Chamber Choir has been invited by Manhattan Concert Productions to be a part of their Broadway Series in a live performance at the world renowned, Avery Fisher Hall at Lincoln Center.  The students will travel for five days to Midtown Manhattan where they will rehearse, reside and experience the hustle of life as a performer in New York City.

These 25 high school students have already begun work preparing the music for Maury Yeston's fantastic creation, Titanic The Musical.  The young performers in the group have grown fond of the work as it depicts the fateful trip that Titanic took in 1912 as it sailed from Southampton, UK to New York City.  It is filled with passion, heart and history!

Please help these outstanding young people to reach their goals of performing in a chance-of-a-lifetime experience at Lincoln Center.  Your donation puts them one step closer to this unbelievable artistic endeavor.

0,"<div class=""routerContentStory-storyBody"" data-v-1df7bf5a=""""><div>
Who We Are

Last summer, a small group of LGBTQ youth of color from across Detroit came together to discuss problems in our community, and teach one another media-making skills that would empower us to create our own home-grown solutions.

A core group of 8 youth committed ourselves to community organizing, making media, and building lasting relationships -- and now we're planning to re-convene, to create an ongoing collective of youth and community allies, committed to solving problems through collaborative media production. To find out more about us, you can check out our website, here.
<div>
<h3>What We Need &amp
In order to be ready for our October launch date, we'll need to raise $6,435 by September 30. This will buy us:
A set of quality media-making equipment that'll last for years to come (including computers, cameras, and audio recorders). We budgeted $4,175 for this.

Groceries! Since each cycle of Detroit REPRESENT! includes a family-style dinner, we'll need to buy groceries for each participant, for each time we meet. We'll save money by cooking the food ourselves, which we figure is a great way to bond and build community, too! This will cost $1,800.

Enough gas money to pick up and drop off each youth participant, before and after meetings. Detroit is a big city, after all, and transportation is a big deal, here. We'll need $460 to cover 12 weeks of transportation.

As Detroiters, nobody knows better than we do that community is the greatest resource we've got. We know that, in times of struggle, we're more capable than ever of creation, and we're committed to tellings stories of resilience, passion, innovation, and empowerment across our city. We also know that our project can't become a reality without financial support. To say thanks, we've thought up perks that include original art and media-pieces, educational sessions, and even a special thank-you dinner and dialogue, where we can get to know each other in person!

If we're not able to meet our entire fundraising goal, we'll spend the money we do raise on purchasing media equipment. The media equipment is the most essential piece of our fundraising goal, because these tools will last for years, and enable us to keep doing the work of community problem-solving in Detroit.
<div>
The Impact

The Mission of Detroit REPRESENT! is to resist erasure and misportrayal by actively engaging in the work of self-education and self-empowerment, to create a revolutionary media alternative that authentically portrays our communities, our lives, and our selves.
Through our project, we'll work to:
<ul>
• Increase authentic, grassroots representation of LGBTQ youth of color in the media
• Tackle serious problems affecting Detroit, such as homelessness, addiction, gentrification, racisim, segregation, violence, and the educational crisis
• Develop and nurture powerful relationships, and solidarity, across communities of color
• Empower LGBTQ youth of color to see themselves as agents of change, in their lives and in the world!
<div>
Other Ways You Can Help
If you're not able to donate, but still want to get involved, we'd love to hear from you! Some additional forms of support we're looking for at this time include:
<ul>
<li>

In-Kind Donations. If you've got a digital camera, old laptop, blank sketchbook, set of colored pencils, or can of spray paint you're not using, send it our way! Any art and media supplies we get will help us make our project a reality!
<li>

Community Allies! If you're local, and want to support us as a community ally, we're looking for some friends and neighbors who no longer self-identify as youth, to help us by providing transportation to and from meetings, supporting fundraising campaigns (like this one), helping us cook weekly dinners, and participating in roundtable conversation.
<li>

Getting the Word Out. Know a youth who might want to get involved? An event we should hook up with? A neighbor looking to volunteer in the fall? We're looking to expand our support base far and wide, so tell a friend! You can use the Indigogo ""share"" feature to tell your online network.
","Who We Are

Last summer, a small group of LGBTQ youth of color from across Detroit came together to discuss problems in our community, and teach one another media-making skills that would empower us to create our own home-grown solutions.

A core group of 8 youth committed ourselves to community organizing, making media, and building lasting relationships -- and now we're planning to re-convene, to create an ongoing collective of youth and community allies, committed to solving problems through collaborative media production. To find out more about us, you can check out our website, here.
What We Need & What You Get
In order to be ready for our October launch date, we'll need to raise $6,435 by September 30. This will buy us:
A set of quality media-making equipment that'll last for years to come (including computers, cameras, and audio recorders). We budgeted $4,175 for this.

Groceries! Since each cycle of Detroit REPRESENT! includes a family-style dinner, we'll need to buy groceries for each participant, for each time we meet. We'll save money by cooking the food ourselves, which we figure is a great way to bond and build community, too! This will cost $1,800.

Enough gas money to pick up and drop off each youth participant, before and after meetings. Detroit is a big city, after all, and transportation is a big deal, here. We'll need $460 to cover 12 weeks of transportation.

As Detroiters, nobody knows better than we do that community is the greatest resource we've got. We know that, in times of struggle, we're more capable than ever of creation, and we're committed to tellings stories of resilience, passion, innovation, and empowerment across our city. We also know that our project can't become a reality without financial support. To say thanks, we've thought up perks that include original art and media-pieces, educational sessions, and even a special thank-you dinner and dialogue, where we can get to know each other in person!

If we're not able to meet our entire fundraising goal, we'll spend the money we do raise on purchasing media equipment. The media equipment is the most essential piece of our fundraising goal, because these tools will last for years, and enable us to keep doing the work of community problem-solving in Detroit.
The Impact

The Mission of Detroit REPRESENT! is to resist erasure and misportrayal by actively engaging in the work of self-education and self-empowerment, to create a revolutionary media alternative that authentically portrays our communities, our lives, and our selves.
Through our project, we'll work to:
Increase authentic, grassroots representation of LGBTQ youth of color in the media
Tackle serious problems affecting Detroit, such as homelessness, addiction, gentrification, racisim, segregation, violence, and the educational crisis
Develop and nurture powerful relationships, and solidarity, across communities of color
Empower LGBTQ youth of color to see themselves as agents of change, in their lives and in the world!
Other Ways You Can Help
If you're not able to donate, but still want to get involved, we'd love to hear from you! Some additional forms of support we're looking for at this time include:

In-Kind Donations. If you've got a digital camera, old laptop, blank sketchbook, set of colored pencils, or can of spray paint you're not using, send it our way! Any art and media supplies we get will help us make our project a reality!

Community Allies! If you're local, and want to support us as a community ally, we're looking for some friends and neighbors who no longer self-identify as youth, to help us by providing transportation to and from meetings, supporting fundraising campaigns (like this one), helping us cook weekly dinners, and participating in roundtable conversation.

Getting the Word Out. Know a youth who might want to get involved? An event we should hook up with? A neighbor looking to volunteer in the fall? We're looking to expand our support base far and wide, so tell a friend! You can use the Indigogo ""share"" feature to tell your online network.",0.0,0,"1 Campaign
