Our Story

We are four high school students raising money to complete the construction of a homeless shelter in Armenia, El Salvador. This is our third year working with the shelter and have traveled down to El Salvador twice and will return in April 2011 to donate the funds. In our third year of involvement we hope to educate others about our cause, inspire them to embark on similar journeys, gain a cultural understanding and connection with El Salvador, and take our fundraising to the next level in order to complete the homeless shelter. The fundraising aspect of our goal is only possible with your help.

Two years ago, we had an idea. We were merely freshmen in high school, and we knew little of global injustices and hardships. During our spring semester, we got connected with Las Señoras de la Caridad, a group of elderly El Salvadorian women who work to better their community of Armenia, El Salvador.

Francesca, one of the four members of our group, has deep connections with the town and organization because of her paternal family's presence in the town. Her grandmother, the leader of this group, spoke to Francesca about a plan to build a homeless shelter. The construction of the shelter had been stopped due to lack of lunds. Francesca, along with her three closest friends: Emma, Emily, and Sara, teamed up to begin a project that would support the continuation of construction on the shelter.

Taking on this project seemed daunting to us. We weren't part of a larger organization and we didn't possess any type of foundation to build off of. But we had an idea: we could do it on our own. While our parents were supportive, not everyone else could grasp the idea of four fourteen year olds initiating such a large project. As one member of the administration at our school asked us, ""You guys are just going to go to El Salvador and build a homeless shelter?"" While we were slightly discouraged by this opposition, our answer was a firm ""Yes.""

Today the shelter stands with three walls and a roof. Over the past two years we have organized bake sales, garage sales, and a letter campaign, in total raising over $3,000. While delivering the money we had raised, we also laid bricks and did other miscellaneous jobs around the construction site. Getting our hands dirty and seeing the money we had raised be put to use was the most rewarding part. We were adopted by Las Señoras de la Caridad our first year there and honored with the name ""Las Chicas de La Caridad.""

Beyond the financial aspect of our cause, we have developed a unique connection with the community we seek to help. Through attending town celebrations we have been able to interact with the people of Armenia. It has been very interesting to explore a community so different from our own, so impoverished, yet so generous and welcoming. Previously the people of El Salvador might have felt differently towards privileged American students, but we hope that our presence in El Salvador has altered their preconceptions. Our connections have made the experience all the more rewarding and a mutual understand between our separate cultures has developed.

This is our third year working with the shelter and have traveled down to El Salvador twice and will return in April 2011 to donate the funds. In our third year of involvement we hope to educate others about our cause, inspire them to embark on similar journeys, gain a cultural understanding and connection with El Salvador, and take our fundraising to the next level in order to complete the homeless shelter. The fundraising aspect of our goal is only possible with your help.

Two years ago, we had an idea. We were merely freshmen in high school, and we knew little of global injustices and hardships. Francesca, one of the four members of our group, has deep connections with the town and organization because of her paternal family's presence in the town. Her grandmother, the leader of this group, spoke to Francesca about a plan to build a homeless shelter. The construction of the shelter had been stopped due to lack of lunds. Francesca, along with her three closest friends: Emma, Emily, and Sara, teamed up to begin a project that would support the continuation of construction on the shelter.

Taking on this project seemed daunting to us. We weren't part of a larger organization and we didn't possess any type of foundation to build off of. But we had an idea: we could do it on our own. As one member of the administration at our school asked us, ""You guys are just going to go to El Salvador and build a homeless shelter?"" While we were slightly discouraged by this opposition, our answer was a firm ""Yes.""

Today the shelter stands with three walls and a roof. Over the past two years we have organized bake sales, garage sales, and a letter campaign, in total raising over $3,000. While delivering the money we had raised, we also laid bricks and did other miscellaneous jobs around the construction site. Getting our hands dirty and seeing the money we had raised be put to use was the most rewarding part. We were adopted by Las Señoras de la Caridad our first year there and honored with the name ""Las Chicas de La Caridad.""

Beyond the financial aspect of our cause, we have developed a unique connection with the community we seek to help. Our connections have made the experience all the more rewarding and a mutual understand between our separate cultures has developed.
Voy--""I go""
We go to El Salvador to work on the construction of the homeless shelters, and develop connections with the El Salvadorian people.

Doy--""I give""We both give and receive when we visit El Salvador. We donate the money we fund raise throughout the year, as well as deliver clothes that we gather in San Francisco.Soy--""I am""What we do defines us.
What We Need & What You Get

We need just $15,000 more to continue the construction of the shelter. The money will be directly used to purchase building materials and labor to construct the last wall, floor, and roof. We will not be spending any money on the trip, solely to better the lives of the less-fortunate of El Salvador.

We have been fundraising since our last trip, and hope to do as much as we can before we leave. If you want to receive an update after our trip to see how the money was spent you can email us at:  voydoysoy@gmail.com or visit our blog: voydoysoy.blogspot.com.
Any amount is greatly appreciated!
Other Ways You Can Help
If you are not interested in donating, you can always spread the word about our project and encourage others to donate. Thanks!",0.0,0,"2 Campaigns

The Integral Heart Foundation
  connecting hearts - evolving culture
  Our Mission: To change culture from the inside out through   person
  -to-person sponsoring and advanced educational programs that
  include the development of mind, body, spirit and emotions.

____________________________________________________________________________________________
Our Vision: We see our work as the beginning of a multi-generational movement whose leaders are empowered to preserve cultural beauty and diversity
column2: to strive for human rights and gender equality
column3: and also to embrace personal responsibility in a global context. Our vision is to teach teachers who we will then sponsor or assist in finding employment in the public school system, or in non-profit run after-school programs. With our current vision by 2050 we are planning to reach 60,000 teenagers.

column1: <table border=""0"" cellpadding=""0"" cellspacing=""0""><tbody><tr>
<td valign=""top"" width=""193"">
<td valign=""top"" width=""445"">

About us: We are dedicated students of   Integral Theory, Evolutionary Enlightenment, Spiral Dynamics, Big Mind and   Zen. Debora Prieto is a native of   Spain, a Zen monk, a facilitator of the Big Mind Process who studied classic   philosophy and graduated from the University of Madrid as an educator of   mentally handicapped children. Mick   Quinn is a native of Ireland, the author of The Uncommon Path who   co-founded and operated several multi-million-dollar companies in New York   City.

Integral Teacher Training University (ITTU): After having overwhelming success with the first two years of our programs, IHF would like to continue to expand the number of people being helped by building the Integral Teacher Training University. This school would offer the most enthusiastic students of the Integral Education/Critical Thinking Program the opportunity to spend 3 years studying the Integral Education Curriculum. Graduates of the university would then teach the Integral Education/Critical Thinking classes in the public high-school system in Guatemala. By 2020, more than 150 jobs will have been created and an estimated 5,000 children will have been exposed to these programs.
<table border=""0"" cellpadding=""0"" cellspacing=""0""><tbody><tr>
<td valign=""top"" width=""157"">
<td valign=""top"" width=""481"">

Endorsement from Ken   Wilber:  ""The Integral Heart   Foundation is doing incredibly   important work, and, just as significant, is doing so by using (and teaching)   Integral Theory. This insures a truly inclusive and comprehensive approach,   something so important (and rare) in today’s fractured world. I send them my   very best regards, and highly recommend you check them out.""
                                                                   
  Ken   Wilber, The Integral Vision
Find us online at:  www.integralheartfoundation.org

column5: the skills needed to work for peace. They say that one can only start contemplating peace if one is at peace- and this is what Innsbruck Peace Program is about. It guides you through the obstacles and provides you with the opportunity of transformation. So I can create a blueprint, a fully fledged plan for integrating new attitudes into the society, breaking apart fears and preconceived approaches, reframing them in a structure that will lead these two torn nations towards reintegration and healing.

column6: part of how I am. It has been quite some time since I realized there is nothing else I can do in my life except to work for a change, for justice, for reconciliation between Israelis and Palestinians. I can try to run away from it, and I did— but somehow I always came back to it. This conflict is part of who I am, and only by working to transform it- can I fulfill my calling.!

column1: ","How will your contribution make a difference?
With your generous contribution I will have the opportunity to complete my thesis, turning it into a fully fledged research work.

My proposal will then be put into practice, putting the foundation of an actual social infrastructure that transcends the current paradigm. Through helping me fund my last semester you will become part of this process
column2: and actively participate in the research.

column1: You will give me the opportunity to gain the further necessary skills relevant for conflict transformation and the chance to elaborate a pragmatic proposal, which is working towards transforming the stagnated status quo in Israel.
With your help, the very final product will be completed by December 2012, and together we can take the next step towards implementation
Why Peace?

Because it is about time. Because ever since I can remember myself there was always war, of some sort. And there were always casualties: Israelis, Palestinians, Jews, Muslims, Christians- everyone's blood is red. The pain of a mother who loses her daughter makes no distinctions. We all hurt
column2: we all bleed- it is about time we start living and not just surviving.

column1: Who am I?

I am an Israeli, who is tired of this conflict. I am a woman who is weary of seeing other women not getting the same opportunities I have because they live on ""the wrong side"" of the wall. I am a Peace Worker, who has been active around the world and would like to bring this work home, so our children can live freely
column2: so we can enjoy the full potential of this country and its people.  I want to bring this home so fear, that nourishes the militaristic ideology, is not longer the main issue that shapes all other realms in the country.

column1: I want to bring this home so you, and I can slowly but surely change the way an entire nation thinks, because only if we change the hearts and minds of the people- the state will follow.

My name is Ori Talmor. I am an MA student at the University of Innsbruck, Austria and I love my country--I want to be part of it--but not like this. I want to be part of a change--and need your help for that.
Peace Studies as a way for Transformation

The Peace Studies program at the University of Innsbruck in Austria is a unique program that was strongly inspired by the UNESCO's famous Manifesto 2000, which proposed to turn the new millennium into a new beginning, an opportunity to change, all together, the culture of war and violence into a culture of peace and non-violence. You can see the program’s website for more detailed description of the program and the curriculum:
http://www.uibk.ac.at/peacestudies/ma-program/
I have one more semester left to graduate, this coming Summer term 2012, and in order to do that I need to raise $8000.
This money will cover 4000 Euro tuition costs (equivalent to $5400), air fare costs (estimated $1500) and living expenses for this period (estimated $1100).
Why this, why me?
Because through this program I can gain the needed tools to work with conflict
column2: the skills needed to work for peace. They say that one can only start contemplating peace if one is at peace- and this is what Innsbruck Peace Program is about. It guides you through the obstacles and provides you with the opportunity of transformation. So I can create a blueprint, a fully fledged plan for integrating new attitudes into the society, breaking apart fears and preconceived approaches, reframing them in a structure that will lead these two torn nations towards reintegration and healing.

column1: Why me? Because I care.
Because it is part of who I am
column2: part of how I am. It has been quite some time since I realized there is nothing else I can do in my life except to work for a change, for justice, for reconciliation between Israelis and Palestinians. I can try to run away from it, and I did— but somehow I always came back to it. This conflict is part of who I am, and only by working to transform it- can I fulfill my calling.!

What would you do if your child was transgender? Because you're looking at a transgender video project on Indiegogo, I'll assume it would probably be okay with you. You'd love them unconditionally and do your very best to help that child grow up to reach their highest potential.

Unfortunately that's not the norm. Many thousands of parents in America will part ways with their child when they discover that their child is transgender. If the child is too young yet to be abandoned, they mistreat and bully the child into conforming unnaturally to the role of their outward gender. And this ultimately leads to years of frustration, confusion, pain and hopelessness for the transgender child.

What these parents don't understand is that being transgender is not ""choosing to be a weirdo,"" as one parent put it, but a natural, biological occurrence - the phenomenon of a girl's brain, heart, and emotions born prisoner in a boy's body, or vice versa. But in America, especially rural America, and in many churches, transgender young people are literally demonized, run out of town, and in many cases, murdered or driven to commit suicide.

The lack of familial and communal acceptance is why 40% of transgender people don't make it to age 30. Transgender people are probably the most misunderstood and wrongly persecuted section of humanity in America.
The root of the problem is simple. It's misunderstanding. And what people don't understand, they fear, hate, shun and condemn.

My film Transgendervention will prevent parents from rejecting and ejecting their transgender children by bridging these gaps in understanding with upfront and in-depth medical, biological, and psychological information from doctors, scientists and therapists who specialize in the study and treatment of transgender people. This documentary will provide vital and current information especially for transgender youth and their families in the hopes that by illuminating and educating them, families will not turn their backs on their transgender children, but continue to love and support them for who they are, and have enough knowledge to be able to spread understanding, themselves.

Many transgender adolescents who may be in the position of ""coming out"" have a narrow and extremely critical window of opportunity to either win the understanding and acceptance of their families or lose those relationships forever. It is my goal, my mission, to provide a film that will explain to these parents what their child is experiencing and why and how these kids can grow up to lead happy and productive lives within a loving and supportive family, and not out on the street. It will be a way they can come out without getting kicked out.

Through interviews with doctors and experts, I will present the biological and physiological reasons why a transgender child may feel that they are ""in the wrong body"" and unable to conform to gender norms. I will present the importance and benefits of aiding transgender kids in their transition at an earlier age so that they can be who they are, and not have to suppress their self-identities throughout their young lives. My interviews will also provide ample, sound advice on bullying, social situations, personal safety considerations, religious opposition and transgender-specific legal issues.
Finally we will demonstrate that there has always been this ""third sex"" of people and briefly give some examples of societal acceptance and admiration of transgender people in other cultures.

This documentary will be a one-stop, best bet source of education for families starting on the path of transition, and will provide them with the resources, knowledge, and reassurance to continue loving and caring for their child.

It is my sincerest hope that this documentary will reach any misguided families of transgender children before they throw their children out of their homes like so many before them, and be a source of light and guidance for others who may have little or no access to the resources and information presented in this film.

Before its release, I will test this film on numerous conservative, uptight, backwards, prejudiced audiences to see if it can bridge the gap in their understanding of trans people as these will be its target demographics and the type of audiences on which it most needs to reach.
This is a monumentally important project. I just need your financial support to make it happen!

Your money will go to fund travel expenses for my interviews of doctors, therapists, and experts in the field of gender dysphoria, and interviews of model families of transgender children. Your money will pay for production, equipment rental, studio time, editing, post-production, music scoring, and distribution costs. I also need funds to enter this documentary in film festivals, not necessarily to win them, but to let people know it is available to them.
The more funds I can raise, the better this film will be. So please, donate.

Additionally, Josh Lehrer, the amazing photographer who did the project ""Becoming Visible: Portraits of Homeless Transgender Teens"" has agreed to let me to use some of his beautiful and heart-rending photographs taken on the streets of NYC in presenting the statistics on transgender homelessness and mortality. Thank you, Josh!
Please support this project right now! Together, we can make a huge difference in the lives of transgender children.
And finally, please know that I am open to your suggestions. If you know something you think I should know, please msg me any time!
PLEASE SHARE THIS PROJECT WITH YOUR FRIENDS!

","What would you do if your child was transgender? Because you're looking at a transgender video project on Indiegogo, I'll assume it would probably be okay with you. You'd love them unconditionally and do your very best to help that child grow up to reach their highest potential.

Unfortunately that's not the norm. Many thousands of parents in America will part ways with their child when they discover that their child is transgender. If the child is too young yet to be abandoned, they mistreat and bully the child into conforming unnaturally to the role of their outward gender. And this ultimately leads to years of frustration, confusion, pain and hopelessness for the transgender child.

What these parents don't understand is that being transgender is not ""choosing to be a weirdo,"" as one parent put it, but a natural, biological occurrence - the phenomenon of a girl's brain, heart, and emotions born prisoner in a boy's body, or vice versa. But in America, especially rural America, and in many churches, transgender young people are literally demonized, run out of town, and in many cases, murdered or driven to commit suicide.

The lack of familial and communal acceptance is why 40% of transgender people don't make it to age 30. Transgender people are probably the most misunderstood and wrongly persecuted section of humanity in America.
The root of the problem is simple. It's misunderstanding. And what people don't understand, they fear, hate, shun and condemn.

My film Transgendervention will prevent parents from rejecting and ejecting their transgender children by bridging these gaps in understanding with upfront and in-depth medical, biological, and psychological information from doctors, scientists and therapists who specialize in the study and treatment of transgender people. This documentary will provide vital and current information especially for transgender youth and their families in the hopes that by illuminating and educating them, families will not turn their backs on their transgender children, but continue to love and support them for who they are, and have enough knowledge to be able to spread understanding, themselves.

Many transgender adolescents who may be in the position of ""coming out"" have a narrow and extremely critical window of opportunity to either win the understanding and acceptance of their families or lose those relationships forever. It is my goal, my mission, to provide a film that will explain to these parents what their child is experiencing and why and how these kids can grow up to lead happy and productive lives within a loving and supportive family, and not out on the street. It will be a way they can come out without getting kicked out.

Through interviews with doctors and experts, I will present the biological and physiological reasons why a transgender child may feel that they are ""in the wrong body"" and unable to conform to gender norms. I will present the importance and benefits of aiding transgender kids in their transition at an earlier age so that they can be who they are, and not have to suppress their self-identities throughout their young lives. My interviews will also provide ample, sound advice on bullying, social situations, personal safety considerations, religious opposition and transgender-specific legal issues.
Finally we will demonstrate that there has always been this ""third sex"" of people and briefly give some examples of societal acceptance and admiration of transgender people in other cultures.

This documentary will be a one-stop, best bet source of education for families starting on the path of transition, and will provide them with the resources, knowledge, and reassurance to continue loving and caring for their child.

It is my sincerest hope that this documentary will reach any misguided families of transgender children before they throw their children out of their homes like so many before them, and be a source of light and guidance for others who may have little or no access to the resources and information presented in this film.

Before its release, I will test this film on numerous conservative, uptight, backwards, prejudiced audiences to see if it can bridge the gap in their understanding of trans people as these will be its target demographics and the type of audiences on which it most needs to reach.
This is a monumentally important project. I just need your financial support to make it happen!

Your money will go to fund travel expenses for my interviews of doctors, therapists, and experts in the field of gender dysphoria, and interviews of model families of transgender children. Your money will pay for production, equipment rental, studio time, editing, post-production, music scoring, and distribution costs. I also need funds to enter this documentary in film festivals, not necessarily to win them, but to let people know it is available to them.
The more funds I can raise, the better this film will be. So please, donate.

Additionally, Josh Lehrer, the amazing photographer who did the project ""Becoming Visible: Portraits of Homeless Transgender Teens"" has agreed to let me to use some of his beautiful and heart-rending photographs taken on the streets of NYC in presenting the statistics on transgender homelessness and mortality. Thank you, Josh!
Please support this project right now! Together, we can make a huge difference in the lives of transgender children.
And finally, please know that I am open to your suggestions. If you know something you think I should know, please msg me any time!
PLEASE SHARE THIS PROJECT WITH YOUR FRIENDS!",0.0,0,"2 Campaigns
|","Butte, United States",https://www.indiegogo.com/projects/transgendervention-2nd-round-of-fundraising/pica

Short Summary
Prudence is 18 years old. She is one of the children that are being supported by Kili Centre. She has always had a huge ambition ‘to learn’. The Kili Centre's motto is that ""Education will set you Free"". In 2007 Prudence was admitted to secondary school education studies. Now having successfully completed her secondary schooling Prudence wishes to continue in a further education program and study Economics. For this reason we are seeking funding to enable Prudence to pursue her dream and also enable her to show other girls at the centre and in the local town that women should also persist in their ambitions in education.

What We Need
The funds are needed to be paid by 15th October 2012 to the University College of Moshi for one year’s education. They include the tuition fees, medical cover, insurance, and student’s administration fees. The funds will also cover her accommodation, meals, faculty requirements and books during the year.

The Impact
Women are not actively encouraged in Tanzania to pursue secondary, let alone further education. We believe that girls who actively pursue these ambitions are setting an example. They show that it is of vital importance to not only fulfill your dreams but to stand up and state your rights to an education as a means to better yourself and your life.

Other Ways You Can Help
The Kili Centre runs many programs and is always grateful for contributions by either time or services or in monetary donations. You can see all the programs the Kili Centre partakes in via the website www.kilicentre.org or contact us for further information.

column2: >Pharmaceutical companies and insurance companies run the health care system! While there is no quick fix to this, one thing we all need is better doctors. In fact doctors of the most extraordinary kind. I am working hard to become one extraordinary doctor. For the last two years I have been working towards advanced degrees to complete my final goal, to earn a joint PhD/MD and become a research doctor. With those credentials, I am devoting my life to changing and improving personal and global healthcare though the marriage of natural healing and complex technologies.

column1: <div><span style=""font-size: 10px

<div>Hard work truly pays off! I have been accepted to the International Scholar Laureate Program - Delegation in Medicine in China this coming June. Unfortunately, I was not awarded the corresponding scholarship which was extremely competitive.  I need your help in funding this extraordinary opportunity. Participation in this program is a huge stepping stone to becoming that extraordinary doctor. My goal is to one day not only cure disease, but prevent it. Please help me get there!
<div>
Who: Me!
What: Participation in this June's International Scholar Laureate Delegation in Medicine in China
<ul>
• This program is highly selective and I was invited to apply because of my membership in the Honor Society, Phi Theta Kappa.
• This program is a 10 day tour around major cities and some rural towns of China, participating in field medicine, taking coursework in medicine and learning about medicinal technologies
• 2 credits towards my degree program
When: June 4, 2013 - June 14, 2013. I need to be fully funded by May 15, 2013.
Where: Beijing, Xi'an, Shanghai &
Goal Amount: $6500. Any and all contributions will begratefully accepted. This amount covers:
<ul>
• The cost of the program $3600
• Airfare, meals, and related expenses (ie my Visa) $2900
Suggested Contribution: So far the average is $50 but any and all will be appreciated!
What you get for helping:
<ul>
• All of my love and appreciation!
• Awesome hand picked postcards and authentic souvenirs from the trip!
• Great pictures!
<div>
<h3><span style=""font-size: 1.17em
column2: >Contributing to help me do this is not just for me, but for everyone. Please help me change and improve the system for all of our health and the health of generations to come.

""Pourquoi seuls les enfants de parents riches pourraient se payer les études qu'ils souhaitent ? Si chaque personne donne ne serait ce que 1euro, ca ne leur retire rien , et ca me rapproche de la réussite de mon projet""
( un compte paypal n'est pas obligatoire : cliquez sur paypal et ensuite vous aurez le choix entre carte bancaire directement et paypal :)
Bonjour ,
Je m'appelle Ryan Bernard , j'ai 19 ans et j'habite à Nantes , en France. Sortant d'un Bac scientifique ,j'ai choisi de me diriger vers l'ostéopathie pour accomplir mon projet de vie .
En effet l'ostéopathie à dans ma vie une place a part entiere puisque je suis baigné dedans:
<ul>

•  Ayant fait plus d'une dizaine de pneumonie à la naissance , je grandis avec des poumons atrophiés a plus de 50%. De ce fait , depuis que je suis nourisson , je suis suivi par multiples kinésitherapeutes et Ostéopathes. J'en comprend donc toute l'utilité et les bienfaits que cette profession peut avoir sur le corps humain.
<ul>

• Ensuite , une des motivations premieres de ce projet est le fait de soutenir ma maman dans sa maladie . Atteinte de plusieurs maladies musculo-squelettiques ( Fibromyalgie, spondylarthrite ankylosante etc.. ) Si je peux , en tant qu'ostéopathe , lui apporter une quelquoncque améliorations a son état de santé , je me donnerais a 300% !

• Enfin , pratiquant le full-contact depuis maintenant 14ans, je suis maintenant  multiples fois champions de France dans toutes les disciplines et j'ai recemment obtenu une medaille de Bronze aux championnats du monde en Slovaquie. Le full contact etant un sport de contact , je vous laisse imaginer les degats et desordres que ca peut engendrer sur le corps humain et la aussi , je constate les merveilles que peuvent effectuer les ostéopathes.
http://www.ouest-france.fr/actu/actuLocale_-Ryan-Bernard-3-e-au-mondial-de-full-contact-_44184-avd-20121002-63714729_actuLocale.Htm

Ayant choisi l'une des meilleures écoles en France, et ayant réussi concours d'entrée , il faut maintenant financer la qualité de l'enseignement. L'année s'eleve a 8000 euros et le chemin vers le diplôme dure 5ans. A 19 ans , je vous laisse imaginer que les fonds ne sont pas presents. C'est la que votre participation prend tout son sens. En faisant un geste, vous pouvez aider à réaliser le reve d'une carriere.

En me faisant confiance , je m'engage a vous transmettre mes resultats qui seront a la hauteur afin d'etre l'un des meilleures dans le domaines . Cela créera un suivi de mon évolution et me permettra de vous montrer que vos dons n'auront pas été inutiles.

Qui n'a jamais eu mal au dos , des maux de tete, ou des problemes visceraux ? en m'aidant , je m'engage , au fil de mon apprentissage a vous aider dans la limite de mes connaissances a vous sentir mieux dans votre corps.
A toute contribution superieur a 30e , je vous offre une consultation gratuite lorsque j'aurais mon diplome.
Les fonds iront entierement et dans leur integralité au financement de l'école.
<div>
L'impact de vos dons sur ma réussite
Certes je pourrais prendre un credit me direz vous mais plusieurs problemes s'installent :
L'etat a mit en place un credit etudiant permettant de financer les études coûteuses, Malheureusement, le plafond possible a ce pret est de 15000 euros , et cela ne me financerait meme pas 2 années .

Ensuite , les banques proposent d'elles memes des prêts étudiants. Ayant fait le tour de toutes les offres , apres des heures et des heures d'entretien avec divers conseillers, la meilleure offre me proposait de payer 870euros le mois direct apres l'obtention du diplome et ce pendant 4 ans ce qui revient a m'enterrer sous d'insurmontables dettes des mon entrée dans la vie active.

Je pourrais aussi trouver un travail etudiants , mais avec un programme de 40 heures de cours par semaine , et cours le samedi , cela ne me laisse pas assez de temps pour cumuler apprentissage et travail assez consequent pour m'autofinancer.
C'est la que vous intervenez, Grace à vous , je pourrais joindre les deux bouts et reussir mes études qui , il me semble est un noble projet !
Je suis quelqu'un de determiné , la dose de travail ne m'effraie pas et mon ambition est plus forte.

Lorsque je me fixe un objectif, je me met des oeilleres afin d'y arriver coûte que coûte. Je n'ai pas peur de remonter mes manches pour obtenir ce que je veux car decrocher ce diplôme est pour moi la plus grande réussite que je pourrais réaliser, ET CE GRÂCE A VOUS !
<div>
Il y a pour vous deux possibilités de m'aider dans ce vaste projet :
Soit vous faites un don du montant qu'il vous convient, n'importe quelle somme est un pas vers ma réussite
Soit vous faites passer le mot , de la publicité pour agrandir le cercle de donateur. C'est par le bouche à oreilles que cela pourra etre rendu possible
Je vous offre mon adresse mail si vous avez des questions a me poser ou si vous voulez communiquer et je vous remercie d'avance : ryanbernard4@gmail.com
Article dans le quotidien 20minutes:    http://m.20minutes.fr/nantes/1174763-appel-dons...
Article sur le site Osteopathie de France : http://www.osteopathie-france.net/page-etudiants/2109-appel-de-ryan-bernard

Education is the great equalizer
....if you can AFFORD IT

I am currently a Senior at Whittier College in California. I started my college education right after high school but withdrew from school when my mother was diagnosed with ovarian cancer. I worked in education for several years, helping my family make ends meet before returning to school full time for my degree. Every semester has been a challenge to afford books and fees. I don't receive financial help from family. My mom is retired/disabled and I am a fully indpendent student. I regularly work 7 days a week as an assistant, dog-walker, babysitter, and tutor.
I've made it this far but I need help to make it across the finish line.
<div>
And so,

Despite maxing out on student loans, I was not able to cover my entire tuition and fees for my final year. Unfortunately, I haven't been able to pay off the entire balance and it continuous to grow each month with hefty finance charges.
<div>

I've learned that despite my demonstrated efforts in paying off the balance on the tuition account, I will not be allowed to participate in graduation commencement unless my balance is brought down to zero.

column2: >I want to do this for my mother...

column1: My reason for initiating this campaign is my mom. I know how much commencement means to her and I don't have the heart to say I can't graduate because I can't afford it.
I would greatly appreciate any contribution that you can make so I can graduate from college and help make my mom proud.
<div>
And of course, even if you can't contribute, sharing the link is greatly appreciated!

0,"<div class=""routerContentStory-storyBody"" data-v-1df7bf5a=""""><h3><span style=""color: rgb(106, 106, 106)

The mission of 100 Strong is to have 100 middle school and high school girls from underserved backgrounds across the Bay Area participate in a year-long leadership training and mentorship program with female UC Berkeley students.
A Big Idea

100 Strong was founded in 2013 by 5 UC Berkeley undergraduate female students, who won the Big Ideas at Berkeley competition in the category of Global Poverty Alleviation with the idea of creating a leadership development program for 100 young women. We taught our very first DeCal (student-run class) for our mentors in Fall 2013 and began the mentorship program in Spring 2014.
Our Mentorship Program

Currently, we are partnering with REALM Charter School in Berkeley, CA, which is composed of 82% socioeconomically disadvantaged students and over 90% minority students. Our mentors meet once a week with their mentees, all eighth-grade REALM students. Each semester, we will also hold a day-long intensive on the Berkeley campus for mentors and mentees. The intensives will involve workshops, leadership and team building activities, and guest speakers to get the mentees involved and more aware of higher education opportunities.
How You Can Help

The crowdfunding goal of $5,000 would help us expand our leadership program to accommodate 100 middle school and high school girls, which has been our ultimate goal since winning Big Ideas. Currently, we have around 50 girls in the program, so we would need almost double our funds to support 100 girls. The crowdfunding goal will help pay for 50 more mentee community projects, supplies for mentors taking our class and mentees taking workshops, and food and guest speaker fees for our two intensives.

We come to you all for help because we believe every one of you has a daughter, sister, or female friend who could benefit from a program like 100 Strong. We all excelled with the help of amazing mentors, teachers, or even leadership programs like ours. We believe our program is relevant to everyone regardless of background because it provides young women with mentorship and an opportunity to practice being a leader, which will prepare them to take on leadership roles in the future. With more women in leadership positions, we strongly believe society as a whole will benefit.
Other Ways to Help

If you like what we do, be sure to share our campaign with your friends and family!
","Our Mission

The mission of 100 Strong is to have 100 middle school and high school girls from underserved backgrounds across the Bay Area participate in a year-long leadership training and mentorship program with female UC Berkeley students.
A Big Idea

100 Strong was founded in 2013 by 5 UC Berkeley undergraduate female students, who won the Big Ideas at Berkeley competition in the category of Global Poverty Alleviation with the idea of creating a leadership development program for 100 young women. We taught our very first DeCal (student-run class) for our mentors in Fall 2013 and began the mentorship program in Spring 2014.
Our Mentorship Program

Currently, we are partnering with REALM Charter School in Berkeley, CA, which is composed of 82% socioeconomically disadvantaged students and over 90% minority students. Our mentors meet once a week with their mentees, all eighth-grade REALM students. Each semester, we will also hold a day-long intensive on the Berkeley campus for mentors and mentees. The intensives will involve workshops, leadership and team building activities, and guest speakers to get the mentees involved and more aware of higher education opportunities.
How You Can Help

The crowdfunding goal of $5,000 would help us expand our leadership program to accommodate 100 middle school and high school girls, which has been our ultimate goal since winning Big Ideas. Currently, we have around 50 girls in the program, so we would need almost double our funds to support 100 girls. The crowdfunding goal will help pay for 50 more mentee community projects, supplies for mentors taking our class and mentees taking workshops, and food and guest speaker fees for our two intensives.

We come to you all for help because we believe every one of you has a daughter, sister, or female friend who could benefit from a program like 100 Strong. We all excelled with the help of amazing mentors, teachers, or even leadership programs like ours. We believe our program is relevant to everyone regardless of background because it provides young women with mentorship and an opportunity to practice being a leader, which will prepare them to take on leadership roles in the future. With more women in leadership positions, we strongly believe society as a whole will benefit.
Other Ways to Help
If you like what we do, be sure to share our campaign with your friends and family!",3.0,0,"1 Campaign
|","Berkeley, United States",https://www.indiegogo.com/projects/100-strong-empowering-young-female-leaders/pica

Why the children need you NOW!
One of
our objectives is to pay the school going costs of children from impoverished
backgrounds. We are nonpartisan and currently support 25 children (15 girls, 10 boys), of these, 5 are refugees
and 1 is living with a disability.
We further have 15 other children who we have committed to start supporting in
2015. We are fully committed to our children’s development, and believe that
education should go beyond cognitive development but should especially
cultivate character, emotional and social maturity, and shape a holistic
individual to fit into the citizenry that we want. Thus, we do not only pay

school going costs, but we also mentor holistically.

We would like to bring our
beneficiaries together for 5 days in November/December 2014 for our annual
‘Children in Freedom Family Workshop’ where we will have a team of mentors to
discuss with them about how to manage the ups and downs of life, how to
identify their talents and related career choices, how to be confident and
employ life skills, and citizenship among others. Mentors will be chosen on the
basis of having similar talents, interests and backgrounds as the children, and
we will employ both an individual and group pedagogical approach. At the end of
the workshop we want our students to be able to know and understand themselves
better, see the potential in themselves and their environments, feel confident
and able to implement change, and be able to share the lessons from the
workshop with other children in their networks. We aim for them to be ‘the

candles that light other candles’.

Children in Freedom changes one child at a time

and one day these numbers will converge to form a country.

We need $14,718.75 for
this workshop. Kindly

give towards this cause and help us mentor our underprivileged students. Also read our profile below to know more about us.

Thank you
so much
Dr Susan

Kiragu-Kanayo

0,"<div class=""routerContentStory-storyBody"" data-v-1df7bf5a=""""> <h3><span style=""font-size: 16px
<blockquote style=""color: rgb(106, 106, 106)
Sometimes, you see the very best in people in response to the very worst of tragedies.

Last Wednesday, after the tragic murder of Corporal Nathan Cirillo and the attack on our Parliament -- just one day after the brutal attack and murder of Warrant Officer Patrice Vincent in Quebec -- we were just like every other Canadian we knew. We felt sad, powerless, and angry.
We found ourselves glued to our smartphones and screens, watching a massive outpouring of emotional content being shared on Facebook, Twitter and media stories.

With a few tweets back and forth, Chad (sitting in his living in room in Toronto) and Kaz (in the back of an Uber car in San Francisco), a fund was created.  Our team quickly grew to include friends and colleagues from all across Canada.

Within 10 hours, our $10,000 goal was achieved, and more than a dozen people had fanned out to create graphics, start a social media campaign, talk to their colleagues and engage the mainstream media. Within 18 hours, our friend Gary Clement from TD Bank, before anyone asked, blew our original goal out of the water by organizing TD, Scotiabank, CIBC and RBC for a combined $80,000 donation. Canada’s four best banks stepped up with massive donations that started a momentum we never dreamed of.

Everyone we reached out to had a shared goal: to show these families that a whole nation grieved with them. Their loved ones didn’t die in vain: they died for us, and they will never, ever be forgotten.

Canada’s foremost charity dedicated to helping veterans and their families, True Patriot Love (TPL) Foundation, stepped up and agreed to be our implementing partner, handling complicated financial, legal and other issues. TPL’s Managing Director, Bronwen Evans, has been there for the regiments and the families throughout. Her leadership has helped us guarantee with absolute confidence that 100% of every dollar raised will reach the families.

Some say that Canadians are apathetic, that online activism is just a bunch of clicks and wasted time. Our answer is simple: in just 7 days, Canadians raised $700,000 for two families whose loved ones were murdered wearing our country’s uniform.  Individuals, religious groups, associations, unions and companies donated as little as $1 and as much as $50,000.
We cannot thank you enough for donating, sharing and stepping up so that all of our grief, shock and sadness could be turned into a living, lasting memorial for these two families.

Our week long campaign is just the beginning. We hope that our fund creates a snowball effect of support of our military families. In the days and weeks ahead, please direct your thoughts, volunteerism and donations to the True Patriot Love Foundation. They honour the sacrifice of members of the Canadian Armed Forces in peace and conflict, helping our real-life heroes and their families.
We stand on guard for them as they did for us. We honour them.
Thank you,
The “Stand On Guard Fund” Committee
Chad Rogers
Kasra Nejatian
Rob Rosenfeld
Katlyn Harrison
Laryssa Christine
Bronwen Evans
Emile Scheffel
Nicolas Ruszkowski
Cody Battershill
Robin MacLachlan
Madi Rougier
Matthew Fortier
Andrew Alves Brander
Andre Albinati
Gary Clement
David Graonvsky
Adam Yahn
Alex Ilchenko
http://truepatriotlove.com

Building a School in Ethiopia
<blockquote style=""font-style: normal

column2: ><span>Did you know that 132 million people live on less than $1 a day? Education provides the strongest opportunity to overcome this level of poverty
column3: however, 72% of school-aged children in Ethiopia do not have access to formal education.  Tapestry Church wants to change this. So this year, we are partnering with an organization called On the Ground to build a school for a rural community in Ethiopia. On the Ground (<a href=""http://www.onthegroundglobal.org/"" rel=""noopener nofollow"" style=""text-decoration: underline
column4: >www.onthegroundglobal.org) supports sustainable community development in farming regions across the world. Our church is on target to raise the $40,000 necessary for the build.

column1: The Impact, Challenges, &

In December, a team will travel to Ethiopia to assist with the build. I am incredibly excited to be a part of this team. The cost of my trip is $2,500. Our team fundraising efforts  will cover $1,000. This amount will cover in-country costs (lodging, food, etc.) and half of my airline ticket. The remaining $1,500 is dedicated to the remaining travel costs and the in-country donations to organizations and people we work with in Ethiopia. During our church’s last trip to Ethiopia, they were able to feed 100 school children, buy a month’s worth of groceries for 8 families, repair two roofs, and employ several Ethiopians for building, driving, and interpreting. We are hoping to do even more this time (in addition to our school build.)

Other Ways You Can Help

To learn more about Tapestry Church and how we are making an impact in our own community and  the world, please visit: www.tapestrysavannah.com. You can also make donations toward our total $40,000 goal for the school build there.

In A Nutshell

• I'm Ross, a 19 year old British student, studying Animal Science at Aberystwyth University.
  • This is the chance of a lifetime. This trip is an amazing opportunity to both enrich my life experience and to improve the lives of people in South Africa with education and sanitation.
• As well as humanitarian work, I will be undertaking conservation work for the preservation of cheetahs and lynx as well as the capture and release of crocodiles.
<li><span style=""background-color: initial
column2:
>The conservation part of the trip is particularly exciting to me as an Animal Science student, and will help to improve my career prospects after graduation.
  • Your funding will make this dream trip possible. Any size of donation will be a massive help.

column1: • A full itinerary can be found on www.vesabroad.co.uk/projects/south-africa.
Here's a breakdown of what your money will buy.
• I need £1800 to fund this humanitarian and conservation trip.
• £1150 of this covers the VESA costs, including three meals a day, accommodation and materials and expertise required for the things we will be building.

• The remaining £650 covers a return flight to South Africa and travel insurance.
  • If the full amount isn't reached, I will meet the rest of the remaining cost through local fundraising in Aberystwyth and my home town.
• Every single person that donates will receive a personal thank you video via email, and everyone will be able to see a final video of the trip at the end.

A Real Life Impact

Feel free to explain more about your campaign and let people know how the difference their contribution will make:

• The group and I will make a real, physical impact on the lives of local people.
  • Vital conservation work for big cats and crocodiles will be done.

• This will all improve both my career prospects after graduation and my life experience as a whole.
  • Monthly updates of this campaign and my local fundraising will be posted on Twitter @VESARossOrchard.
Risks &

• I'm a committed and passionate individual, willing and able to work for the good of others.
  • The work will be tough, and raising the money will be difficult, but I believe it can be achieved.

Other Ways You Can Help

If you can't donate any money, that's fine! You can help in other ways:

• Tell your friends about me! Facebook, Twitter, Tumblr, anything to make some noise and help my cause
  • Use the Indiegogo share tools to spread this as far as possible.

And that's it! So, if you can, please back this campaign, and tell as many people as you can.

column5: > For too long now the East End has been neglected and used merely to make up the numbers at Westminster with a politician focused solely on furthering her career, not the interests of the people of the East End.
column9: >This area defied the Labour party in September's Independence Referendum and we can do so again in Mays General Election.
column13:
>For a £10 an hour living wage, an end to trident nuclear weapons, an end to the Bedroom Tax, a strong devolution of powers for Scotland beyond the Smith Commission and for a locally based, working class MP earning a workers wage who'll ensure our voice is heard and valued at Westminster, vote Liam McLaughlan and the Scottish Socialist Party.

column7:
>Project Background

Hello supporters! We are the Indiana Bicentennial Children's book team from Butler University located in Indianapolis, IN. As you may (or may not) know, Indiana will be celebrating its 200th birthday on December 11, 2016! To commemorate this momentous anniversary, our team has written and illustrated a children's chapter book titled The Gifts of Indiana: A Tale of Three Birthdays and One Grand Adventure. Our interdisciplinary team has been officially endorsed by the Indiana Bicentennial Commission, and has been hard at work since April 2014 to get this book written, illustrated, published and printed for Indiana's Bicentennial celebration. Since Indiana state history is taught in 4th grade classrooms, we've shaped this historic adventure book around the target audience of 4th grade students. With your help, we can reach our goal of spreading Indiana's history in a fun, engaging way to 4th grade classrooms all over Indiana.

column1: Here's a sneak peek of what it's all about!

It's December 11, and twin siblings Anna and Bobby are excited to celebrate their tenth birthday. What Anna and Bobby don't realize is that they share their birthday with their home state: Indiana. After blowing out their birthday candles, the twins start to understand what it really means to leave a legacy and make a difference.
Author Biographies
is Kim Van Wyk and I am a senior at Butler University, majoring in Elementary
Education. Indianapolis has been my home all my life. Something fun to know
about me is that I have sung in an Irish pub with an Irishman and his
guitar.

column3:
/>

Hey guys! My name is Matt O'Brien and I am a senior Elementary education major here at Butler. I am originally from Strongsville, Ohio, and one unique fact about me is that I do stand up comedy!

column1: Luc, and I'm one of the authors of <i>The Gift of Indiana: A Tale of Three
Birthdays and One Grand Adventure. I am an Elementary Education major,
and I have minors in Mild Intervention and Peace and Conflict Studies. My
hometown is a suburb of Chicago called Northbrook in Illinois. One thing that
some people may not know about me is that I love to paint. I hope you love the
book!
column3:
/>

Hello future supporters! My name is Katy English and I am a double major in Elementary Education and Special Education. My hometown is River Forest, Illinois, and a fun fact about me is that I was an Irish dancer for 11 years!

/>

Hi friends! My name is Chloe Pahl, and I am a double major in Marketing and Entrepreneurship &
column4: Innovation in the College of Business here at Butler. My hometown is Green Bay, Wisconsin (Go Pack Go!) and an interesting fact about me is that I was a competitive curler for 8 years and have been to five national curling competitions!

column1: Hi everyone! My name is Catrina Cranfill and I am a double major in Marketing and Management Information Systems in the College of Business at Butler. I am originally from Indianapolis, Indiana, and am so excited to be a part of this book celebrating this state's 200th birthday! A little-unknown fact about me is that my brother (Kasey) and I were named after one-hit wonders!
column3:
/>

Hello! My name is Eileen Carroll, and I am originally from Columbus, Indiana. I am currently in my final year of pharmacy school at Butler. A fun fact about myself is that I have a pet frog at home. I am excited to begin sharing this book with children and families in Indiana!

column1: <div>
<h3>What We Need &amp
column2:
What You Get
  • We are asking for $2,500 and have chosen to do flexible funding. After our printing and publishing fees have been covered, any remaining profits will go toward giving books away to students as well as supporting future interdisciplinary book projects at Butler.

column1:
• If we do not raise a minimum of $1,500, we will have to publish our book as an e-book instead of as a soft cover chapter book.
  • Check out our fun perks on the right side of the page! With the gift of education in mind, most of our gifts include giving books away to our donors. The more money we can raise, the more books we can give to you and to others!

• The expected release date of our book is the Spring of 2015.

    • The Impact

    • This collaborative effort will allow us to not only share this fun story with students from Indiana, but will also showcase Indiana history for non-Indiana students, family members, and friends! We are confident that those who are not from the state of Indiana will enjoy this timeless story just as much as Indiana residences.
• We feel our project will inspire students of all ages to unleash their creativity, as well as prove that there is no dream that is too big!
<div>

Other Ways You Can Help

Like us on Facebook! https://www.facebook.com/BUIndianaBicentennialChildrensBook
Follow us on Twitter! @GiftsofIndiana
Use the Hashtag #ShareTheGifts on Twitter or Instagram to spread our message!
Check out the Indiana Bicentennial website here: www.indiana2016.org
Thank you so much for taking the time to read our campaign! There is no donation too small--every dollar is appreciated and will help us reach our goal!

We are confident that those who are not from the state of Indiana will enjoy this timeless story just as much as Indiana residences.
We feel our project will inspire students of all ages to unleash their creativity, as well as prove that there is no dream that is too big!
Other Ways You Can Help Like us on Facebook! https://www.facebook.com/BUIndianaBicentennialChildrensBook
Follow us on Twitter! @GiftsofIndiana
Use the Hashtag #ShareTheGifts on Twitter or Instagram to spread our message!
Check out the Indiana Bicentennial website here: www.indiana2016.org
Thank you so much for taking the time to read our campaign! There is no donation too small--every dollar is appreciated and will help us reach our goal!",8.0,0,"1 Campaign

column1:
Every child deserves the chance to benefit from having a direct relationship with healthy and organic food. But social inequality deprives many kids of this privilege.  By creating organic fruit orchards at low-income schools, Common Vision has created this relationship for more than 100,000 children.



Your support of this campaign will allow us to bring our innovational brand of education to 30 additional schools and 15,000 more kids in the next year alone and to scale to hundreds more in the coming decade.  Together we can continue to give children the equal access to the healthy food they deserve.



Many of us take for granted the privilege of eating healthy foods.  Whether you purchase from farmer’s markets, grocery stores, or harvest from your own gardens - access to quality food pays real dividends, in immediate and long-term development, health, and wellbeing.
column2:
>Now, imagine how not having access to fresh and healthy foods would impact your life.  

For many of the 3,655,624 students receiving free and reduced-priced lunches in California, public schools often provide their only healthy meal options. For the 100,000 kids at 215 public schools, Common Vision plays a critical role in student health by delivering access to free, fresh, organic fruit.



Common Vision’s California School Orchard Project provides 100,000 low-income students with fresh fruit every year.  Schools looking to nourish and educate their students contact us every week requesting an orchard.  Unfortunately the wait list for our program can be as long as 3 years
column3: without your support, we cannot help them.
column4:
>We’re counting on you, today, to become the newest supporter of Common Vision with a contribution.
Every bit helps us get to our goal.

column1: <h3 style=""text-align: center
column3: >Gardens are a cornerstone of nutritional and environmental education in schools across the country.

column1: <div><span style=""font-weight: normal

Unfortunately in many California schools, gardens are under-staffed, under-utilized, and just not growing much food.  In a modern world wrestling with countless ecological and health crises, it is more important than ever for all children to be environmentally and nutritionally literate.

Formed in 2005, Common Vision is a non-profit that delivers inspirational environmental education.  Over the past 10 years we’ve planted more than 6,000 fruit trees throughout California and built a reputation for improving the lives of students and teachers.  Not only do Common Vision orchards produce 150,000 lbs of organic fruit every year (so far), they are also living classrooms where kids learn about environmental science, climate change, nutrition, and teamwork.
We have accomplished all this with amazingly small budget, and are currently struggling  to support our existing network of schools and to respond to new requests for help.

We have a solid foundation of dedicated and knowledgeable staff, the needed tools and materials, an army of energized volunteers, and over a decade of experience to help us meet the overwhelming demand and expand Common Vision orchards to 1,000 schools by year 2025.
<div>
<span style=""color: rgb(0, 0, 0)
column4: >Common Vision takes a unique approach of using fruit trees and other perennials to create extremely high-yielding, low-maintenance, and low-cost school gardens

column1: <h3><span style=""color: rgb(106, 106, 106)
column8: >This allows students to eat tons of fresh fruit, while freeing teachers and garden coordinators to focus on education instead of maintenance.

column1: <div>

In addition to growing the number of schools we reach, we’re setting our sights on deeper interactions with each site and its students. Your funds will go towards developing school curriculum, launching dozens of easily adopted orchard activities, expanding the orchards to include understory gardening and perennial vegetables, and even to build outdoor kitchens among the trees. With your help, these efforts will nourish, educate, and inspire millions more children.
Working with hundreds of schools throughout California, we’ve had the incredible opportunity to educate students on how important their relationships with food are
column2: through fostering community action we have empowered students to take to direct responsibility for their own health, as well as that of the planet for future generations.  By 2025, we're aiming to have orchards in 1,000 schools, and it all starts now with you.

column1: Gardens are a cornerstone of nutritional and environmental education in schools across the country.

Unfortunately in many California schools, gardens are under-staffed, under-utilized, and just not growing much food.  In a modern world wrestling with countless ecological and health crises, it is more important than ever for all children to be environmentally and nutritionally literate.

Formed in 2005, Common Vision is a non-profit that delivers inspirational environmental education.  Over the past 10 years we’ve planted more than 6,000 fruit trees throughout California and built a reputation for improving the lives of students and teachers.  Not only do Common Vision orchards produce 150,000 lbs of organic fruit every year (so far), they are also living classrooms where kids learn about environmental science, climate change, nutrition, and teamwork.
We have accomplished all this with amazingly small budget, and are currently struggling  to support our existing network of schools and to respond to new requests for help.

We have a solid foundation of dedicated and knowledgeable staff, the needed tools and materials, an army of energized volunteers, and over a decade of experience to help us meet the overwhelming demand and expand Common Vision orchards to 1,000 schools by year 2025.
Common Vision takes a unique approach of using fruit trees and other perennials to create extremely high-yielding, low-maintenance, and low-cost school gardens.
This allows students to eat tons of fresh fruit, while freeing teachers and garden coordinators to focus on education instead of maintenance.

In addition to growing the number of schools we reach, we’re setting our sights on deeper interactions with each site and its students. Your funds will go towards developing school curriculum, launching dozens of easily adopted orchard activities, expanding the orchards to include understory gardening and perennial vegetables, and even to build outdoor kitchens among the trees. With your help, these efforts will nourish, educate, and inspire millions more children.
Working with hundreds of schools throughout California, we’ve had the incredible opportunity to educate students on how important their relationships with food are
column2: through fostering community action we have empowered students to take to direct responsibility for their own health, as well as that of the planet for future generations.  By 2025, we're aiming to have orchards in 1,000 schools, and it all starts now with you.

A 6.7 earthquake hit near Kathmandu, Nepal Saturday leaving the city damaged, unfortunately a high death rate and countless hurt. During my travels I stayed at a children's hostel in Kathmandu for 3 weeks during which they treated me like family, gave me a bed, food and plenty of love. Fortunately the kids I lived with are okay but their community is damaged and need help during this time. The money will be used to help with whatever the children's home needs (medical care, rebuilding funds etc.) as well as their neighbors.

AFGHAN GIRLS’ SCHOOL – A WOMEN EMPOWERMENT COURSE

A follow-up course for women (aged 17-32), primarily graduates from my prep course in 2011, to upgrade their communications skills in English,  to study women affairs as well as to enhance their status and their potential roles in the local society.
What is the project?

To raise $35,000 to continue the advanced level training of a class of 35 Afghani women, i.e. to run a 2-month follow-up course in Pul-e Khumri, Afghanistan for students who completed my prep course in 2011 as well as to continue the basic level English language training of approx. 100 local women.

Depending on the total amount raised in this campaign, the duration of the training will be adjusted, hopefully it will be increased in one-month increments. Contributions amounting to US$10,000 in excess of the target amount would facilitate the extension of the course by approx. 1 month.
Any amount raised in this campaign, no matter how large, or small, will be utilized towards the training of this class of young ladies.

Last year I implemented a prep course for a group of 35 young ladies utilizing a generous grant from the US State Department and I prepared the graduates for participation in my Afghani women empowerment course.
Students consolidated their English language skills and we laid a solid basis for their advanced studies. Now is the time to launch their follow-up course.

Approx 50 % of the donations are for the cost of the teacher, including safe transport and accommodation, the cost of the local NGO partner, and 50  % for logistic and IT support, security and maintenance, the operation of the school building, including electricity, internet subscription and fuel in the winter (depending on the timing of the course).

I and the students will send you a personal email plus updates incl. photos about daily life around the school and in the streets of scenic Pul-e-Khumri. We will also place your name in the donor list on the wall of our classroom
We will have all sorts of goodies, genuine Afghani products from the local arts and crafts market, in store for everyone who makes a larger contribution.
Who are we?
My name is Sandor Mesterhazy, I am a teacher and interpreter. I am Hungarian and I live in a small town near Budapest.

I have visited Afghanistan several times since 2004. I escorted VIPs as a freelance interpreter and I worked there as a teacher under two different government contracts. I developed two tailor-made training methodologies for Afghani students. I implemented my interpreter training course for a large group of Afghani men in 2008 / 2009 and one of the graduates from that course is my teaching assistant (TA) now. I designed an Afghan women training methodology, which I field-tested and verified over the past few years.
Students from my 2011 prep course in Pul-e Khumri would attend the envisaged “intercultural communications course for women”, which will be financed from your generous contributions now.

Students are local Pul-e Khumri residents, some of them graduated from high school last year and some of them have a college diploma. One student is a young mother who attended classes with her baby girl in her arms. She turned out to be one of the hardest working and most successful students in the course. Students accepted considerable risks in the current situation when they enrolled in a course strictly designed for local women. We managed to build good relations with leading members of the local community and we encountered no objections to the education of women in Pul-e Khumri.
My TA is an accomplished local Afghani teacher and interpreter.

My local NGO partner is the Social Support for Women and Children Organization (SISWC), which was established in June 2008 as a non-profit, non-governmental, non-political organization. SISWC has operated in different locations in Baghlan Province in the implementation of training courses. SISWC has worked in close cooperation with a range of local Afghani and foreign implementing partners. SISWC has given each project a unique “Afghan face” and facilitated the acceptance of a women empowerment projects in local communities.
Where is it?

Pul-e Khumri is the capital of Baghlan Province in northern Afghanistan. The school is situated on an abandoned industrial site along the main road to Kabul. Unfortunately, the building and the whole site are in a sadly dilapidated condition, which is not considered to be unique in a country that was ravaged by 35 years of foreign occupation, civil war and the ongoing war on terror.
Why this project?

I and my Afghani NGO partner selected a group of young ladies whose English language proficiency was good enough to enroll in a course that prepared them for advanced studies in English language communications and in women affairs.

The course won the hearts and minds of students and members of the local community alike. These young ladies, graduates from the prep course are very well prepared to take advantage of the envisaged inter-cultural communications course, to find a good job and to pursue a professional career in the future.

It would be a waste of our efforts and funds that were invested in the prep course, if the training did not continue. I escorted my students half way towards a better future and it would be a grave mistake to abandon them now. We made them believe that education would pave their way towards a better future. I want to go with them all the way to that objective.
I request you to fund this project to make the students' dreams of a better future come true.
Why now?

The situation in this region of Afghanistan is still relatively peaceful and the education of women is still possible. The training of these young ladies should resume and their studies should be completed as long as the prevailing circumstances permit it.
We are in a hurry, since the withdrawal of US and ISAF troops in 2014 is drawing near and no one can predict how long this window of opportunity remains open to us.

I decided not to wait for a new government grant, I decided to promote and safeguard my students’ interests and raise the necessary amount of funds for the continuation of their studies as soon as possible.
Why us?

No other similar training opportunity has been available to local women in Baghlan Province. It was my initiative to launch the prep course, I designed the training methodology and I secured funding for this class of young ladies. I and my local partner NGO pooled our efforts to launch this course and unless we sustain the momentum of this project, no other advanced training opportunity in English will be available to local women.

We have an outstanding track record in the local community, we won the hearts and minds of a lot of local people. We can continue the training of women in the same school and in the course, but it is highly unlikely that in the less and less tolerant atmosphere anyone else could start any new training program.

Much to my regret, cultural and religious reasons as well as safety considerations prevent me from enclosing at least some of the very few photos that I took of my students in class and in the graduation ceremony.

Nevertheless, I will attach a series of photos of the neighborhood, the industrial site where the shoo-an-zay (Pashto for school) is situated and the school building itself. Also, I enclosed te photo of a beautiful Afghani war rug.

Please find enclosed a few photos of the dilapidated building and our classroom, which may seem to be a pretty awful place by western standards, but which were perfect for our purposes, while we were conducting our daily classes there together in a warm and friendly atmosphere for several months.

Even if you just can’t contribute, it  doesn’t mean you can’t help. Please tell your friends and neighbors about my campaign. For this purpose, please feel free to use the Indiegogo share tools!

Short Summary

My name is Luna and I am a Senior at High Tech High Media Arts (HTHMA) in San Diego, CA. At HTHMA, we have a program called One World Week, a weeklong period for students in 9th-12th grade to experience the world around them outside of the classroom.

This year, 14 of my peers and I are trying to go to Bali and Singapore to learn volunteer at a local school, and learn about these cultures first-hand. Unfortunately, with more than half of us coming from low-income backgrounds, we do not have the funds to get there alone. With your help, 15 students will be able to experience the Balinese culture first hand.
<h3><strong>What We Need &amp
In order to make this trip happen, we need to raise at least $34,000. Even if we are unable to raise this much money, every little bit will help us to achieve our goal. No donations will be wasted!
The Impact

Over the years, High Tech High has seen the difference experiences such as this trip have made in student's lives. Many students have never been out of the state before, let alone another country. By donating money to our trip, you are helping many students experience something completely different that they most likely would not be able to otherwise. This trip is not just about the volunteer work or the fun we will have. it's about the memories and knowledge we will gain as a group that will change our lives forever.
<div>
Other Ways You Can Help
We understand that not everyone can donate to our trip, but you can still help our cause! Help get the word out about our trip and share our page today!
